headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call and Webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; Cheryl Scully, our C
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call and Webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; Cheryl Scully, our Chief Financial Officer; and Jon Ferrando, our Executive Vice President, responsible for M&A. 
Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Robert Quartaro and I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have. 
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments. Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from such forward-looking statements. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our press release issued earlier today and our SEC filings, including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules will be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release, which is available on our website at investors.autonation.com.
And now, I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record quarterly earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.02 for the fourth quarter, a 23% increase on a per share basis as compared to $0.83 for the same period in the prio
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record quarterly earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.02 for the fourth quarter, a 23% increase on a per share basis as compared to $0.83 for the same period in the prior year. This is our 17th consecutive quarter of double-digit year-over-year growth in quarterly EPS from continuing operations. 
For the full year, adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $3.49 was also an all-time record, up 17% over prior year.
Fourth quarter 2014 revenue totaled $5 billion, an increase of 12%, driven by stronger performance in all our major business sectors. We also reported an increase of 12% in operating income to $227 million. Revenue for the full year was $19.1 billion, up 9% over prior year. Our operating income for the full year was $821 million, an increase of 11% over prior year.
During 2014, AutoNation repurchased 9.4 million shares for an aggregate purchase price of $485 million. As of February 2, 2015, AutoNation has approximately 113 million shares outstanding.
Our planning assumption for 2015 industry new vehicle unit sales is above 17 million for the year. We believe that replacement demand, attractive products and great consumer credit will continue to support sales.
2015, we will continue to invest in our digital storefront called AutoNation Express. We successfully began our launch in December 2014, and we'll continue to roll out AutoNation Express from coast-to-coast.
I'll now turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Cheryl Scully.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the fourth quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $117 million or $1.02 per share versus adjusted net income of $102 million or $0.83 per share during the fourth quarter o
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the fourth quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $117 million or $1.02 per share versus adjusted net income of $102 million or $0.83 per share during the fourth quarter of 2013, a 23% improvement on a per share basis. There were no adjustments to net income in the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjustments in net income in prior periods are included in the reconciliation provided in our press release. 
In the fourth quarter, revenue increased $524 million or 12% compared to the prior year and gross profit improved $80 million or 11%. SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 67.9% for the quarter, which represents a 70 basis point decrease compared to the year ago period. 
In addition to solid cost control, SG&A as a percentage of gross profit, benefited from seasonally strong premium luxury vehicle sales, which supports new vehicle gross profit dollars as well as our expense leverage.
Net new vehicle floor plans was a benefit of $15.2 million, an increase of $3.4 million from the fourth quarter of 2013, primarily due to higher floorplan assistance. 
Floorplan assistance increased primarily due to higher new vehicle sales. Floorplan debt increased sequentially, approximately $323 million during the fourth quarter to $3.1 billion at quarter end due to increased inventory balances.
In December, we amended our unsecured credit agreement by extending our maturity 3 years, lowering our borrowing costs by 25 basis points, increasing our revolving credit facility to $1.8 billion and eliminating the term loan.
In the amended facility, the maximum leverage ratio remains at 3.75x and the maximum capitalization ratio increased from 65% to 70%.
We continue to secure financing at favorable terms due to our strong operational results, in addition to our investment-grade debt profile, disciplined financial management and robust cash flow generation.
Non-vehicle interest expense increased to $22.1 million compared to $21.7 million in the fourth quarter of 2013, primarily due to higher debt balances.
At the end of December, we had $1.1 billion of outstanding borrowings under the revolving credit facility and a total non-vehicle debt balance of $2.1 billion. This was an increase of $195 million compared to September 30, 2014. The provision for income tax in the quarter was $71.6 million or 38%.
From October 1, 2014 through February 2, 2015, we repurchased 1.4 million shares for $69 million at an average price of $49.35 per share. AutoNation has approximately $281 million of remaining board authorization for share repurchase. As of February 2, there are approximately 113 million shares outstanding and again, this does not include the dilutive impact of stock options.
Our leverage ratio increased to 2.3x at the end of Q4 compared to 2.2x at the end of Q3. The leverage ratio was 2.2x on a net debt basis, including used floorplan availability and our covenant limit is 3.75x.
Capital expenditures were $52 million for the quarter and $192 million for the full year 2014. Capital expenditures are on an accrual basis and exclude operating lease buyouts and related asset sales.
Our quarter end cash balance was $75 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity, resulted in total liquidity of $770 million at the end of December.
In 2014, we continue to demonstrate the strength and flexibility of our business. During the year, we repurchased 9.4 million shares for $485 million and announced acquisition and add points with $550 million in expected future annual revenues.
Looking forward, we remain committed to driving shareholder returns through strong operational execution as well as investments in strategic initiatives, acquisitions and share repurchase.
Now let me turn you over to our President and Chief Operating Officer, Mike Maroone.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cheryl, and good morning. We're extremely pleased with our fourth quarter performance, where we delivered revenue and gross profit growth across the business, an exceptional 4.5% operating margin, an all-time record quarterly and annual EPS and
componenttext:
Thank you, Cheryl, and good morning. We're extremely pleased with our fourth quarter performance, where we delivered revenue and gross profit growth across the business, an exceptional 4.5% operating margin, an all-time record quarterly and annual EPS and the 17th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth.
As I continue, my comments will be in a same-store basis compared to the period a year ago. 
Starting with sales. Total gross profit for variable operations was up 10%. On a per vehicle basis, total variable gross was $3,450 per vehicle, an increase of $71 or 2%, driven by solid contributions from used vehicles and customer financial services.  Combined, new and used same-store unit volume was up 8%.
In the quarter, we've retailed 80,800 new vehicles, an increase of 6,700 units, or 9%, generating new vehicle revenue of $2.9 billion, up $277 million or 11%. New vehicle gross profit of $179 million grew by $10 million or 6%. Gross profit per new vehicle retails at $2,220, it was off $67, or 3%, compared to a year ago, attributable in part to continued pressure in the Import segment as well as the introduction of several new premium luxury models in the quarter a year ago that commanded higher margins at launch. Sequentially, compared to Q3 2014, gross profit for new vehicle retail increased $344 due to the seasonal lift in Premium Luxury, an achievement of several manufacturer year-end volume-based incentives, which were higher in the quarter than anticipated.
Looking ahead, we expect gross profit per new vehicle retail to return to normalized levels, in sync with typical seasonality and subject to market conditions. At year-end, our new vehicle inventory was 54 days compared to 62 days a year ago.
Turning to used vehicles. We had another solid performance in the quarter at $984 million, retail used vehicle revenue increased $75 million, or 8%, on the sale of 52,500 used vehicles, an increase of 3,500 units or 7%. Retail used vehicle gross profit of $88 million was up $11 million, or 14%, and gross profit per used vehicle retail was $1,679, an increase of $97 or 6%. 
We are focused on optimizing the acquisition of used inventory as well as pricing our used vehicles to market. We continue to see opportunity in used due to the increasing supply of used vehicles, both from new vehicle trades and off lease and feel we are well-positioned looking forward. 
At December 31, our used base supply was 38 days compared to 35 a year ago, aligning with our intent to build inventory for Q1.
Rounding up the variable side of the business is customer financial services, where in the quarter, we achieved a record gross profit per vehicle retail of $1,444, an increase of $71 or 5%. Total gross profit for CFS of $193 million was up $24 million, or 14%, compared to the period a year ago. 
We continue to be extremely pleased with our performance here and regain focus on the overall customer experience, continuous improvement in store level of execution and growing long-term customer retention through value-added product offerings.
Next, customer care, which encompasses our service parts and collision business. In the quarter, customer care revenue of $713 million increased by an impressive 10%, or $65 million, and customer care gross profit of $298 million grew 8% or $23 million.
Expanding on gross, warranty gross increased 24%, supported by continued strong retail activity, which represented just over 5% of our total customer care gross. Customer pay gross were 3% in the quarter and accounted for nearly 40% of the total customer care gross.
This also marked our 18th consecutive quarterly increase in customer pay gross as we continue to focus on growing our customer pay business while ensuring we address recalls for our customers.
And finally, collision gross was up 11% in the quarter.
I'll note that looking ahead, we maintain our outlook that customer care gross comps will be in the mid-single-digit range as we previously discussed asset elevated recall activity.
In closing, I'd like to thank our 24,000 associates for their contributions to an outstanding quarter and year as well as their commitment to delivering a peerless customer experience.
As was announced on January 15, I'll be retiring from AutoNation on April 1. As that transition begins, I'll share that it's been a privilege to serve the company for the past 18 years. I am proud of our accomplishments and confident about the company's succession plan, including Bill Berman taking on the Chief Operating Officer position.
I'm very optimistic about the future of AutoNation, where my family remains significant shareholders.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jon Ferrando.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and thank you for your leadership and partnership for the last 18 years. We completed 2 acquisitions since year-end, Mercedes-Benz of Reno in Nevada and a Volkswagen store in the Atlanta market that will operate as AutoNation Volkswagen Ma
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and thank you for your leadership and partnership for the last 18 years. 
We completed 2 acquisitions since year-end, Mercedes-Benz of Reno in Nevada and a Volkswagen store in the Atlanta market that will operate as AutoNation Volkswagen Mall of Georgia.
In 2014, these stores collectively generated approximately $120 million in revenue and sold approximately 3,400 new and used retail units.
Both franchises are located in attractive auto retail locations and facilities. We are excited about adding our 21st Mercedes-Benz franchise to the AutoNation family. It's a great way to enter Reno, Lake Tahoe, an attractive auto retail market with good demographics.
As of today, our store portfolio number is 284 franchises and 234 stores in 15 states, representing 34 manufactured brands.
Looking forward, we will continue our strategy of pursuing acquisitions and add points that enhance brand representation within our auto retail markets as well as markets that can be supported by our existing management infrastructure. We will continue to be selective and prudent with our capital with a focus on investing to produce strong returns and long-term shareholder value.
I will now turn it back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jon. Mike, I'd like to personally say, thank you for being my partner for the last 18 years. Thank you for your dedication for the last 18 years to AutoNation, and we had our strongest year ever. We set all-time records in 2014. It is a great f
componenttext:
Thank you, Jon. Mike, I'd like to personally say, thank you for being my partner for the last 18 years. Thank you for your dedication for the last 18 years to AutoNation, and we had our strongest year ever. We set all-time records in 2014. It is a great final chapter.
Thank you for having succession plan that well positions Bill Berman and the entire operation team to continue their march of providing a peerless customer experience.
Mike, after 60 quarters together, I want to thank you on behalf of my self, AutoNation's 24,000 associates for your 18 years of contribution and dedication to our fine company. And we wish you nothing but success in your future endeavors.
With that though, you need to remain and answer some questions here. We'd throw the floor open.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from James Albertine with Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from James Albertine with Stifel.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry to see you go, Mike, but you've done a great job, and we wish you the best and look forward to working with Bill in the future. Mike Jackson, if I may, on a higher level, just in terms of how important you think consolidation is to the trajectory of
componenttext: Sorry to see you go, Mike, but you've done a great job, and we wish you the best and look forward to working with Bill in the future. Mike Jackson, if I may, on a higher level, just in terms of how important you think consolidation is to the trajectory of AutoNation going forward. And quite frankly, if you can opine on some of the bigger acquisitions that have been announced recently among sort of the outsiders, if you will. So with Berkshire entering the fray, there's some conversation now around source fund management, looking at an acquisition in the dealer space as well. So what does that say about the bigger picture dealer outlook long-term? What it does it do for purchase multiples? And why do you think their -- or Buffett, at least, targeted a private group versus a public group?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I certainly welcome sophisticated astute investors such as Warren Buffett and George Soros to auto retail. It's not a new experience for the auto industry, particularly not for AutoNation. I would observe that Eddie Lampert invested in us 15 years a
componenttext: Well, I certainly welcome sophisticated astute investors such as Warren Buffett and George Soros to auto retail. It's not a new experience for the auto industry, particularly not for AutoNation. I would observe that Eddie Lampert invested in us 15 years ago and owns 20% of the company today. And Bill Gates, through his fund, Cascade, and Michael Larson have been with us for over a decade and own 15% of the company. So having astute, sophisticated, long-term investors is not new to us, and I welcome more to auto retail. I think it's absolutely a validation of the attractiveness and sustainability of auto retail. Now as far as the pace of consolidation, I see no change. There'll be a gradual evolutionary consolidation into larger  entities' hands whether they're public or private. If I look at it right now, the publics are at 7% to 8%. And if I take the top 100 retailers in America, it's around 20%. And if I go back a decade ago, that was maybe 15%. So -- and why is the consolidation gradual and evolutionary? It's because you need willing sellers to come to a reasonable price, a fair price as to what to acquire the business for. There's a lot of emotion invested in independent entrepreneurial family businesses that many cases have existed for over a generation. And if you try to preemptively buy that strictly on price, the only way you can get that deal done is to dramatically overpay. And certainly, the industry, for over a decade, has shown an understanding of this fact and the discipline around price. And certainly, they knew entities that you called out have all built their enterprise based on paying a fair value price, not overpaying. So I don't think there's any change there. I think it will be a gradual evolution. I think though having larger players in the future is inevitable, that as private entrepreneurs build up bigger entities, you need more financial muscle and a bigger balance sheet to go to the next level of consolidation. But again, it will be a gradual evolution. Now whether those entities are public or private, I think that's a separate story. The big story is the top 100 is approaching 20%. And where that line gets drawn between public and private, we'll move over time. As far as why Warren Buffett buys what he buys, that's a question you should address to Mr. Buffett. I met him years ago at Bill Gates' home, he asked me questions about auto retail and the auto industry, so I'm not surprised that he's in the space, but as to why Warren finally does what he does, it's far beyond my pay grade and I can't give you any insight there.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I may ask a quick follow-up though, just given your size and how well you've done recently, in particular, in January results, theres' some consternation out there that I'm sensing as it relates the credit market, whether it's the risk of rising rates
componenttext: If I may ask a quick follow-up though, just given your size and how well you've done recently, in particular, in January results, theres' some consternation out there that I'm sensing as it relates the credit market, whether it's the risk of rising rates or what have you. Just want to know from your experiences, what would be the first indicator or sort of concern metric that you'd be focused on the most, is it residual values on the used side? Is there something out there that you're looking for that would make you incrementally negative? Because it doesn't sound like the credit market has tightened up, it sounds like it's just as available and supportive of a strong SAR in 2015, at least early 2015.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, here's how I look at the credit market and what I watch for. There's -- the American consumer has approximately $12 trillion of all forms of debt outstanding, of which auto loans are less than $1 trillion, let's say, $900 billion with the lowest defa
componenttext: Yes, here's how I look at the credit market and what I watch for. There's -- the American consumer has approximately $12 trillion of all forms of debt outstanding, of which auto loans are less than $1 trillion, let's say, $900 billion with the lowest default rate of any form of credit. Lower than mortgages, credit cards, student loans, whatever form of credit you want to point to. People pay their car loans. And by the way, that $900 billion is secured. It's not unsecured like credit cards or student loans, it's secured. And the industry had never bought into the folly that a car is an appreciating asset like the financial service industry said about houses, that they would always go up. Now the mindset of lending in automotive is it's a depreciating asset, it always goes down and structure the loan accordingly. So I watch the lending. Now there is some risk on residuals and leasing, particularly around the price of gasoline because as the price of gasoline moves with a lot of volatility, it really affects the retail value of whatever's coming back into that market. So if you have very high gasoline prices and your preses [ph] are coming off lease, you're going to do very well. If you have very low gasoline prices, and you have trucks coming off lease, you're going to do very well. So that's the only wildcard that lenders need to watch for. As far as subprime, for us as a company, when we retail 100 vehicles, 8 our them are financed by a subprime loan. So it's a small part of the business for us at our level. That's not to say you can't find further out on the price spectrum a subprime business that is different, but for AutoNation, that's not an issue. As far as the overall interest rates, we expect gradual increases to start in 2015. We're thinking like 50 basis points in the course of the year and a bit more in 2016. But all that looks very manageable. So as far as 2015 is concerned, I think the safest prediction I ever made about industry unit volume breaking through 17 million or being above 17 million is one of the lowest risk predictions I've ever made. 17 million will happen in 2015. We're very confident about that. And if I look at the pent-up demands, economies moving at a better rate, there'll be good years after that. Too soon to say what the actual number will be.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Mike Maroone. It's really been a pleasure and you've obviously done a great job. I do have one question for you though, specifically, as you depart, will you be carrying sort of a bat phone that you can be consulted on very quickly if nee
componenttext: Congratulations, Mike Maroone. It's really been a pleasure and you've obviously done a great job. I do have one question for you though, specifically, as you depart, will you be carrying sort of a bat phone that you can be consulted on very quickly if need be? I know you have great succession planning, but will you still be available?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I consider myself a friend to the company and will always be supportive of the company and always be available to them. Thank you, John.
componenttext: I consider myself a friend to the company and will always be supportive of the company and always be available to them. Thank you, John.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Second question, as we look at the consolidation of the dealership base, it can happen in many ways and what we've seen is like you said the top 100 group's becoming a greater percentage of the total, but we're also seeing -- saw a massive re
componenttext: Okay, great. Second question, as we look at the consolidation of the dealership base, it can happen in many ways and what we've seen is like you said the top 100 group's becoming a greater percentage of the total, but we're also seeing -- saw a massive reduction in dealerships from 2008 to where we are right now. As we think forward about this consolidation, Mike, is it possible that this happens without big acquisitions? Meaning, with your digital strategy and your focus on trying to expand your footprint and your reach, is there the potential to really consolidate tails without making big acquisitions as long as you have a presence and a margin?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that principle has actually, John, guided our acquisition strategy for the last decade, that digital is a game-changer, brick-and-mortar, still is valid and relevant. Therefore, for fulfillment and customer care base, you need all the brands in a gi
componenttext: Well, that principle has actually, John, guided our acquisition strategy for the last decade, that digital is a game-changer, brick-and-mortar, still is valid and relevant. Therefore, for fulfillment and customer care base, you need all the brands in a given market to really make it work. It simply cost too much to ship product from market to market, and to really control the entire experience and bridge the great gap that exists, you need to control it from end to end. You need to own the store, literally own the store, not have a relationship with the store, own the store that you can dictate the processes and the technology in the store, and you need to control and own the website. That's what we're pursuing as a totality. Now whether that leads to more rapid consolidation, that's bigger than I would predict. As far at it being a significant competitive advantage, absolutely.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a second question. If we think about AutoNation Express just being launched in December, a lot of digital spending going on, a lot of spending on sort of the national branding exercise. Has there been any benefit from that to date in your r
componenttext: Okay. And then a second question. If we think about AutoNation Express just being launched in December, a lot of digital spending going on, a lot of spending on sort of the national branding exercise. Has there been any benefit from that to date in your results? Or is that largely still in the investment process and we'll see benefits further down the line?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's definitely in the investment process, John. Its -- benefits are down the road. Although I think branding AutoNation, that was part of this, that's been a tremendous benefit to our associates after 2 years to attract talent, retain talent. As far as a
componenttext: It's definitely in the investment process, John. Its -- benefits are down the road. Although I think branding AutoNation, that was part of this, that's been a tremendous benefit to our associates after 2 years to attract talent, retain talent. As far as awareness in the marketplace of the name AutoNation within our markets -- Mike, you might have the exact numbers -- it has already surpassed our legacy name, think about that. Some legacy names, we've been pounding on for 100 years and in 2 years, the name AutoNation has surpassed it in awareness and consideration. The next piece of the puzzle is transactional websites and traffic to our website. Traffics to our website is growing at double digit, significant double-digit rates. Our own websites now generate more business than all the third parties combined. So there's significant progress, but if I look at the level of investment relative to those factors, I would say we're still very much in investment period and I would say that we'll certainly be for all of 2015. As far as my conviction, are we on the right course or not? I'm 100% convinced. 100% convinced that the strategy we are pursuing over time will be a sustainable competitive advantage for AutoNation, which is one of the hardest things to do in business. Mike, do you have any marketing awareness numbers for us?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, but I think you're -- I don't have those numbers in my head, but you're correct in saying that every one of our former local market names has been surpassed by the AutoNation. There's not one that stands taller, and that's within a very short period.
componenttext: No, but I think you're -- I don't have those numbers in my head, but you're correct in saying that every one of our former local market names has been surpassed by the AutoNation. There's not one that stands taller, and that's within a very short period.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So think about that, John. In 2 years, on the AutoNation brand, we've surpassed the legacy names, some of which were 100 years old.
componenttext: So think about that, John. In 2 years, on the AutoNation brand, we've surpassed the legacy names, some of which were 100 years old.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's very impressive. But if we just think about this in totality though, it sounds like there's still a little bit of heavy sledding through '15 but you'll reach a tipping point as we go from '15 to '16 where the investment fades and the benefits co
componenttext: Yes, it's very impressive. But if we just think about this in totality though, it sounds like there's still a little bit of heavy sledding through '15 but you'll reach a tipping point as we go from '15 to '16 where the investment fades and the benefits come in or the benefits at least you serve and outweigh, will they be ongoing investment?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not doing so bad. In the meantime, if you look at the fourth quarter. So we can afford to be in an investment phase, and it's -- the internal thinking is that it will be gradual, it's not an inflection point where you flick a switch and you go,
componenttext: Yes, we're not doing so bad. In the meantime, if you look at the fourth quarter. So we can afford to be in an investment phase, and it's -- the internal thinking is that it will be gradual, it's not an inflection point where you flick a switch and you go, "Aha!" or checkmate on everybody. We're really not -- I'm really thinking in a 5-year block from today. So imagine, this has been underway for 7 years. We're now implementing in the marketplace. The initial reaction is fantastic. If I look out 5 years from now, I'm convinced we'll be looking back on this investment phase and say, "That was great money that we invested. " I'm convinced of it. But we have to go through an investment phase. And it's -- I should be clear, it's not cheap. I've been very straightforward, it's over $100 million, well over $100 million if you combine what we're investing in the brand, and you combine what we're investing in technology to make our website attractive and transactional, plus the processes that have to change in the store. But this total integrated technology solution where a customer can seamlessly move back and forth between an online experience and in-store experience, we are convinced is the Holy Grail for automotive retail. And you combine that with the brand where you control and know your own website, and you have a fulfillment footprint with a customer care to cover your fixed cost. This is a winning combination.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Seems like you're going to grab a lot of market share over time...
componenttext: Seems like you're going to grab a lot of market share over time...

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me just say on that, John. So where -- the position I want to be in is to decide whether I'm going for share or margin. I want to control the margins in the future. If you become overdependent on third-party lead providers, you will lose control of yo
componenttext: Let me just say on that, John. So where -- the position I want to be in is to decide whether I'm going for share or margin. I want to control the margins in the future. If you become overdependent on third-party lead providers, you will lose control of your margin. So this isn't as much about having control of our future margins, which I'm absolutely convinced we will have much more say over, or I can do the calculation and say, we go for share or it's a combination of the both. But that's the position you want to be in.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's very impressive. Then just 2 last very specific questions. Parts and service obviously came in pretty strong. You guys are still talking about mid-single digits. It seems like from the recall activity that -- particularly GM is calling for this
componenttext: Yes, it's very impressive. Then just 2 last very specific questions. Parts and service obviously came in pretty strong. You guys are still talking about mid-single digits. It seems like from the recall activity that -- particularly GM is calling for this year versus last year on cash, it's almost -- at least half is coming in, in 2015. So it means that the recall that was at the earliest curve of this is waved, is only half done. It seems like you'll get as much recall activity in '15 as in '14 if not more and the 0 to 5-year-old car fleet continues to grow. So I'm just curious why you think there might be that slowdown in parts and service or that's just a reasonably conservative planning assumption? And then the...

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a reasonably conservative -- that's our base plan plus exceptional recall is the way to think about. And it's very hard to predict exactly what the level of recall work that will be done, particularly on recall on vehicles this old, whether people
componenttext: That's a reasonably conservative -- that's our base plan plus exceptional recall is the way to think about. And it's very hard to predict exactly what the level of recall work that will be done, particularly on recall on vehicles this old, whether people really bring them in or not. So mid-single digits is without the recalls, that's just what we're going to do with the business, and then you can put the recall on top of it if you can figure out how much is actually going to be done, good for you. On the Takata recall, we estimate the industry has completed about 10% of that. And on the ignition switch, it's about 40% complete, 50% complete. Now the question is, on vehicles that old, will that continue in 2015? We just don't know the answer.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's tough to call. And then just lastly, specifically, on used vehicle pricing. I mean, there's this constant consternation that pricing is going to come down, Manheim Index is holding up reasonably well. You and the other public groups as well as C
componenttext: Yes, it's tough to call. And then just lastly, specifically, on used vehicle pricing. I mean, there's this constant consternation that pricing is going to come down, Manheim Index is holding up reasonably well. You and the other public groups as well as CarMax continues to post positive average transaction prices in your used vehicle business. I know there's some mix that's going on here. But it seems like the reality of what's happening in the market is still very strong and as we get miles driven growing and the supply vehicles is still relatively constrained, we could be in an environment where used vehicle pricing holds up better than people are generally perceiving. I'm just trying to understand what the disconnect is between this consensus view that used vehicle pricing is coming under pressure but it's actually really not. And I'm just trying to understand what you think is going on there.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, if we look at the chart of the vehicle return rate, it definitely increases in 2015. It hasn't happened yet, but it will in 2015. And what does that to valuations, we will adjust for. But here's my point, John. Let's say, used values come down becau
componenttext: Well, if we look at the chart of the vehicle return rate, it definitely increases in 2015. It hasn't happened yet, but it will in 2015. And what does that to valuations, we will adjust for. But here's my point, John. Let's say, used values come down because there's more availability. Let me see if I have that straight. My acquisition cost is going down and I have more of them to buy. If I look at our used car capabilities that we've developed, that makes me even more optimistic about the used car business. I think we're really at a point where we can succeed either way. Now could there be an adjustment period if it moves with a lot of volatility quickly? Well, of course. There could be a quarter where that happens. But then on a new level and I have more space between -- I have more margins space between used cars and new cars. So we're optimistic about used cars business and we think whatever is coming will be -- there won't be extreme volatility to it. I think that's the most important point, and we'll be able to adjust to whatever the new circumstances are. But you well could be proven right that the demand for used cars is such that even with improved supply, and there will be improved supply in 2015, prices don't move that much. We'll have to wait and see. We'll manage it either way.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Patrick Archambault with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Patrick Archambault with Goldman Sachs.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up actually, first, on the SG&A leverage piece. It does, indeed, look like based on the fourth quarter, as you pointed out, not doing too badly in terms of the fixed cost absorption despite the fact that you've got some investments
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up actually, first, on the SG&A leverage piece. It does, indeed, look like based on the fourth quarter, as you pointed out, not doing too badly in terms of the fixed cost absorption despite the fact that you've got some investments that are ongoing here. So as we look through 2015, where that -- there's still some investment to go. Is there still an ability to see improved leverage in spite of this, like you saw in '14?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Pat, this is Cheryl. We're really focused on cost discipline. So if you look at the fourth quarter with the seasonally strong period largely in customer care, you get some benefits from that on the gross side. Now if you look at the full year, we wer
componenttext: Yes, Pat, this is Cheryl. We're really focused on cost discipline. So if you look at the fourth quarter with the seasonally strong period largely in customer care, you get some benefits from that on the gross side. Now if you look at the full year, we were just under 70%, and that's where we continue to target. So we think as we look into '15 and forward, goal is still to continue being under 70% despite that continued investment in digital. There's some different levers to pull there and gross will dictate some of that, but that still remains a goal. We know that there's leverage there to be had. I think fourth quarter seasonally tends to be very strong. You do get some seasonality in SG&A, but certainly, remain focused on staying below 70%.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just on that, I mean, in terms of the performance, is it just kind of pure operating leverage that is kind of on your ongoing business that's offsetting the incremental cost? Or there are other savings that are still forthcoming? You mentioned, for in
componenttext: And just on that, I mean, in terms of the performance, is it just kind of pure operating leverage that is kind of on your ongoing business that's offsetting the incremental cost? Or there are other savings that are still forthcoming? You mentioned, for instance, less reliance on lead regeneration companies, which I know are kind of expensive, maybe just an example.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I look at the -- at our cost for the lead --- third-party lead providers, my goal is to invest that money in the AutoNation brand rather than third-party lead providers. So we pay third-party lead providers x amount of money and it generates 14% of our
componenttext: If I look at the -- at our cost for the lead --- third-party lead providers, my goal is to invest that money in the AutoNation brand rather than third-party lead providers. So we pay third-party lead providers x amount of money and it generates 14% of our business today. I would like to take that x amount of money and spend it on the AutoNation brand and whether that customer comes to us on the telephone, driving-in or through our website, it really doesn't matter to me. But my view is every time I spend $1 on the AutoNation brand, it's a double win. I sell a car today and I build awareness for the future. Whereas, when I spend money with third-party lead providers, yes, I get to sell a car today, but they take that money and build their brand and get the future sale. And maybe I get a shot at that, maybe I don't and most likely I have to compete on price to get to the next one. So this is -- over time, when we successfully execute this shift of resources from third-party lead providers to AutoNation, I think, over time, it makes the company stronger and stronger. But my idea is not that I can simply take that money and spend it with lead providers and not spend it anymore. I don't see that. I think it's reallocated to AutoNation marketing.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And one last one for me just on the parts and service. I think getting back to maybe John's question, I understand how you guys are thinking about it. But more specific to the cadence of it, it does seem right based on, actually, wha
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And one last one for me just on the parts and service. I think getting back to maybe John's question, I understand how you guys are thinking about it. But more specific to the cadence of it, it does seem right based on, actually, what you provided there, 40% completion on ignition, 10% on the Takata and now obviously, we have TRW's issue. It does seem that -- at least in the first part of the year, right, there's something to sustain pretty high comps, especially seeing the comps in the beginning of last year where it isn't as tough. So is there a kind of one of these things where we can expect sort of similar performance maybe in the first half and borrowing anything you need kind of slows down in the second?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, that's for you to -- you'll figure it out. Directionally, we've given you a very clear picture of how we think about it. I don't see anything -- I would take exception in your assumptions. But we just don't know when legal vehicles, how
componenttext: Well, I would say, that's for you to -- you'll figure it out. Directionally, we've given you a very clear picture of how we think about it. I don't see anything -- I would take exception in your assumptions. But we just don't know when legal vehicles, how people are going to react. That's all I'm pointing out. So we've given you the number that we feel good about we're going to grow. Customer care, mid-single digits plus whatever exceptional recall activity comes out and the where and when, we'll get back.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Rick Nelson with Stephens.
componenttext: The next question comes from Rick Nelson with Stephens.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats to Mike Maroone as well. It's been a great run, Mike. Thanks for all the help over the years.
componenttext: Congrats to Mike Maroone as well. It's been a great run, Mike. Thanks for all the help over the years.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd like to ask you about what appears to be market share gains in the fourth quarter and then in the car side, if you could comment there whether you think this branding and digital spend, if it's really starting to kick in? Well, I think our share is st
componenttext: I'd like to ask you about what appears to be market share gains in the fourth quarter and then in the car side, if you could comment there whether you think this branding and digital spend, if it's really starting to kick in? Well, I think our share is stable to plus. Mike, is that how would describe it there?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a hard thing to pin down exactly, so I would say it's probably on the plus side.
componenttext: It's a hard thing to pin down exactly, so I would say it's probably on the plus side.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it is plus, and we've got benefit from our mix as well and our geography, so it's been good.
componenttext: I think it is plus, and we've got benefit from our mix as well and our geography, so it's been good.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the strength in January unit sales appear to have accelerated. Is that just easier compares with the weather? Or is this the underlying business?
componenttext: And the strength in January unit sales appear to have accelerated. Is that just easier compares with the weather? Or is this the underlying business?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you go back a year ago, Rick, we were -- I was very clear that I thought January and February last year were nominally and not a true indication of the market and thought we'd end up at $16.5 million and we ended up at $16.5 million. So something
componenttext: Yes. If you go back a year ago, Rick, we were -- I was very clear that I thought January and February last year were nominally and not a true indication of the market and thought we'd end up at $16.5 million and we ended up at $16.5 million. So something definitely, whether it was severe winter weather or some other economic blah, was going on in the first quarter last year that was temporary. What that means from a comp point of view is January and February are easy comps. I think our sales last January were flat, '14 versus '13. So think about that, no increase whatsoever. So that's a very easy comp so you can't take January now and extrapolate it for the full year. So -- but to be off to such a good start for the year, with everything else as I've described as the backdrop, means our forecast that the industry will do $17 million looks pretty clear.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And finally, if I could ask about Texas, if you've seen any change there versus the rest of the chain.
componenttext: And finally, if I could ask about Texas, if you've seen any change there versus the rest of the chain.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've seen no change in Texas yet. No change in the fourth quarter, no change in January. But the anecdotal stories of what's going on in Houston and other parts of Texas would lead one to believe that most likely, Texas will have to make some sort of adj
componenttext: We've seen no change in Texas yet. No change in the fourth quarter, no change in January. But the anecdotal stories of what's going on in Houston and other parts of Texas would lead one to believe that most likely, Texas will have to make some sort of adjustment to this new price of petroleum. And we're watching for it, but it hasn't happened yet. There's a reasonable expectation.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Paresh Jain in for Ravi. Mike, let me first congratulate you on a successful career on behalf of the entire Morgan Stanley team here, and thank you for your help over the years. A couple of questions, just following up on Rick's question on Texas
componenttext: This is Paresh Jain in for Ravi. Mike, let me first congratulate you on a successful career on behalf of the entire Morgan Stanley team here, and thank you for your help over the years. A couple of questions, just following up on Rick's question on Texas and if I could make it more generic for all the oil states. It was obviously a very strong volume quarter for you, but have there been any early signs of lenders in these oil states becoming less aggressive at lending terms which may have impacted sales?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Mike Maroone. We haven't seen any pullback from the lenders. And I think Mike's already said the business is tracting quite well. Our South Texas business, which is right in the energy corridor, performed very well in the fourth quarter and hav
componenttext: So this is Mike Maroone. We haven't seen any pullback from the lenders. And I think Mike's already said the business is tracting quite well. Our South Texas business, which is right in the energy corridor, performed very well in the fourth quarter and have not seen signs of disruption yet, either on the lender side or on the volume side.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one quick follow-up on the Smart Choice program. Any early indications of impact on either share, gross profit or even transaction times on those 30 stores?
componenttext: And just one quick follow-up on the Smart Choice program. Any early indications of impact on either share, gross profit or even transaction times on those 30 stores?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. It's very early. We're just in South Florida, and it's less than a month old. So too soon to say. The anecdotal reaction of the stores and the consumers is extremely positive. Those that have used it absolutely love it. The recommendation on re
componenttext: All right. It's very early. We're just in South Florida, and it's less than a month old. So too soon to say. The anecdotal reaction of the stores and the consumers is extremely positive. Those that have used it absolutely love it. The recommendation on repeat referral business is off the chart, but that's just an initial indicator and it's really too soon to draw any conclusions from that.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's good to know. And lastly, one housekeeping one. Parts and services, obviously, the other customer care business rather posted strong double-digit growth. Margins kind of declined year-on-year. Any color on what's driving that year-on-year decli
componenttext: And that's good to know. And lastly, one housekeeping one. Parts and services, obviously, the other customer care business rather posted strong double-digit growth. Margins kind of declined year-on-year. Any color on what's driving that year-on-year decline?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone. First, let me point out that our total margin for the whole company was stable at 15 5 [ph]. We did see a small -- some small pressure in the customer care margin, but it's really about a change we made and how we calculated it our reco
componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. First, let me point out that our total margin for the whole company was stable at 15 5 [ph]. We did see a small -- some small pressure in the customer care margin, but it's really about a change we made and how we calculated it our reconditioning rates and some of that moved to used vehicle margin. When we look at the core service business of customer pay and warranty, our margins were actually up slightly. So the margins that are subject to the marketplace were up and the ones we controlled internally, we made some tweaks to and created that margin compression. But overall, the total margin for the company is stable.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Colin Langan with UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from Colin Langan with UBS.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Any color on -- can you give an update on your website strategy? Where are you and how should we think about the IT spending directionally year-over-year? Is it going to accelerate or is it going to be about the same as this year?
componenttext: Any color on -- can you give an update on your website strategy? Where are you and how should we think about the IT spending directionally year-over-year? Is it going to accelerate or is it going to be about the same as this year?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. Our investment in AutoNation Express will increase significantly in 2015 as compared to 2014, that includes investment in the brand, includes investment in IT capabilities and includes investment in the store. As far as features that
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. Our investment in AutoNation Express will increase significantly in 2015 as compared to 2014, that includes investment in the brand, includes investment in IT capabilities and includes investment in the store. As far as features that have to be in the store. The IT part of that, Cheryl, do you have any color on that?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think when you look for total year, I'd say that's the main metrics to look at -- or I mean, the fact that we'll target below the 70%. I think the cadence of the actual investment is going to vary quarter-by-quarter. From a capital perspective, I'd say
componenttext: I think when you look for total year, I'd say that's the main metrics to look at -- or I mean, the fact that we'll target below the 70%. I think the cadence of the actual investment is going to vary quarter-by-quarter. From a capital perspective, I'd say the costs are up within the aggregate, but nothing, I think, that's not sustainable within the context of the total business.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015

componenttext: The next question comes from David Lim with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk a little bit more about your e-commerce strategy. It looks like you guys are putting in a lot of money. Is this something that you may consider monetizing in the future to other dealer groups that may not be competing in your geographi
componenttext: Just wanted to talk a little bit more about your e-commerce strategy. It looks like you guys are putting in a lot of money. Is this something that you may consider monetizing in the future to other dealer groups that may not be competing in your geographical areas?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I really don't foresee that. That's not in our plan. We've created a common technology platform across the company, centered out of our shared resource center in Dallas, Texas. Within that, critically, is our lead management system and our customer relati
componenttext: I really don't foresee that. That's not in our plan. We've created a common technology platform across the company, centered out of our shared resource center in Dallas, Texas. Within that, critically, is our lead management system and our customer relationship management system, which is proprietary, called Compass. And now we're building capabilities on our site -- transactional capabilities on our site that has literally been several years in development to protect -- to perfect how they work. So it's quite an effort. And the key to make the whole thing really compelling and different is that we control it from end-to-end. We own the websites, we own the stores, and we prescribe exactly how everything works from the store back to the website, back and forth in real time. So when you talk about giving this out to someone else, well, if they don't have the store process to align with how we're designing everything, it immediately falls apart. It's no longer indicated technology solution that works from end-to-end. So we have people approach us and ask us, but I don't know how much benefit it would really be worth, and it's not in our plan.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. The other question I have is with the advancement of all these vehicles, the technology whether it be engine powertrain, infotainment systems, et cetera, do you guys eventually foresee the DIFM guys being squeezed out and more of the car park out
componenttext: Got you. The other question I have is with the advancement of all these vehicles, the technology whether it be engine powertrain, infotainment systems, et cetera, do you guys eventually foresee the DIFM guys being squeezed out and more of the car park out there even outside of warranty start to flow back more into the authorized dealer base?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly -- if we look at, strategically, what's happening here, on the one hand, in principle, the quality of the car is significantly improved year after year. However, the complexity and sophistication of the car goes up exponentially year af
componenttext: Well, we certainly -- if we look at, strategically, what's happening here, on the one hand, in principle, the quality of the car is significantly improved year after year. However, the complexity and sophistication of the car goes up exponentially year after year, and those who have the infrastructure and expertise to care for them, as you already point out, becomes less and less. So if we can address the issue of why customers would leave the authorized dealer network, both convenience and cost, then the percentage we can retain for our customer care business is a significant opportunity. So we think we can grow our customer care business open-ended. The only question is the rate of growth.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. So I mean, in theory, Mike, if these become -- like, if we look at electric vehicles, OEM electric vehicles or hybrid vehicles or as you said, exponential improvement in technological complexity, in theory, the requirement of capital is going to
componenttext: Got you. So I mean, in theory, Mike, if these become -- like, if we look at electric vehicles, OEM electric vehicles or hybrid vehicles or as you said, exponential improvement in technological complexity, in theory, the requirement of capital is going to be really be limited to you guys as well as some of the bigger groups. The local mom-and-pop shops may not have the capital to actually compete on that level. I mean, would that be a fair commentary for where it's going forward? And given that, I mean, wouldn't that give you a little bit more optimism of maybe even touching double-digit same-store sales growth on a more consistent basis way out in the future?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, way out in the future. So I think I'm not going to go beyond the statement that we can grow our customer care growth. Our customer care business open-ended. The only question is the rate of growth. I will give you an update on the rate of growth year
componenttext: Yes, way out in the future. So I think I'm not going to go beyond the statement that we can grow our customer care growth. Our customer care business open-ended. The only question is the rate of growth. I will give you an update on the rate of growth year-by-year, but I'm not putting a stake on the ground today for, let's say, 2022. But in principle, you have a very valid point. I've long thought that, believe that, and I think that's how it's playing out in the marketplace.

componenttext: Berman, you got big shoes to fill, my friend, so good luck. I wanted to ask you on the digital expense, just very simply, how do we think about the spending going forward? Do you see a step up in your spending plans in 2015 and into 2016? Or are you already at a level where you're just going to continue at the same pace?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Things are going so well. We're stepping up the investment in 2015. If I go back and look at it, remember when we launched the AutoNation brand, we stepped up investment in that and said, "Okay. Then we'll see how it goes, and we'll see what the next step
componenttext: Things are going so well. We're stepping up the investment in 2015. If I go back and look at it, remember when we launched the AutoNation brand, we stepped up investment in that and said, "Okay. Then we'll see how it goes, and we'll see what the next step was ". Well, quite frankly, it went so well, that we stepped up investment in 2014. We accelerated the plan in 2014, both investing in the brand and investing in digital technology. Our results from 2014 are so good, we're stepping up the investment in 2015, both in branding and in digital. And we still have gateways where we can slow down if we get reactions that would say we didn't get it all right. But so far, everything is green lights. And I'm not shooting for a point where an Aha! moment where you can then, say, "Look at this number, look at this number, it all worked out." But we're convinced we're on the right track, and so we're stepping up investments in 2015.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Brett, I would just add that it really becomes part of AutoNation's ongoing operating cost every time. So unlike rebranding, which was a discrete launch event, digital look at incorporated become part of AutoNation's ongoing operating cost over time a
componenttext: And Brett, I would just add that it really becomes part of AutoNation's ongoing operating cost every time. So unlike rebranding, which was a discrete launch event, digital look at incorporated become part of AutoNation's ongoing operating cost over time as we switch from a traditional bricks and mortars only strategy to more of an omni-channel and digital web strategy.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then switching gears, just looking at your used vehicle same-store sales, the cadence. The beginning of this year or 2014, kind of flat. In the back half of the year, you pushed up into that 6% to 7% range. What is it that's driving the improvement? I
componenttext: And then switching gears, just looking at your used vehicle same-store sales, the cadence. The beginning of this year or 2014, kind of flat. In the back half of the year, you pushed up into that 6% to 7% range. What is it that's driving the improvement? I don't see easier comps driving the improvement, it seems as though either may be increased supply or maybe some internal changes at AutoNation. What is it that's driving that improvement towards the back half of 2014?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I answered that question on the call of the second quarter 2014, where I clearly said that we were understocked for various operating reasons in the first half of the year, and we felt that we have taken measures in the second quarter to address it and I
componenttext: I answered that question on the call of the second quarter 2014, where I clearly said that we were understocked for various operating reasons in the first half of the year, and we felt that we have taken measures in the second quarter to address it and I was very optimistic about used car sales for the second half of the year. And Mike, how did we do?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's exactly it. We've had a couple of very strong quarters back-to-back where we had volume increases and margin expansion. I think it's our third straight quarter of really nice margin expansion. The team's worked really hard, we've got an excellent u
componenttext: That's exactly it. We've had a couple of very strong quarters back-to-back where we had volume increases and margin expansion. I think it's our third straight quarter of really nice margin expansion. The team's worked really hard, we've got an excellent used car team, they're working really hard on pricing, working really hard on getting the right product. And then the wind is there from an off lease perspective yet. 23% improvement in '14, 19% improvement in '15 and vehicles coming off lease. So supply is a big deal, but I think the execution by our operating team from coast-to-coast really was a big driver as well.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then if I could just one final conceptual question for you, Mike Jackson. Let's see, Tesla. Mr. Elon, he would kind of suggest that at some point in time, we will be able to seemingly disaggregate the franchised auto dealer, let's say, between the OEM
componenttext: And then if I could just one final conceptual question for you, Mike Jackson. Let's see, Tesla. Mr. Elon, he would kind of suggest that at some point in time, we will be able to seemingly disaggregate the franchised auto dealer, let's say, between the OEM and the customer, let's say, possibly, by servicing the cars over the Internet so on, and so forth. I mean, that's just, kind of conceptually, it seems like is what we're -- what he's driving towards or suggesting might happen to some degree. I guess my thought is, how do you feel about that relative to your business model?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't see it as an issue for us at all. We are investing $150 million, $200 million per year in just bricks-and-mortar, not counting the investment in digital and a huge percentage of that is for customer care to expand our capacities there. And as I ju
componenttext: I don't see it as an issue for us at all. We are investing $150 million, $200 million per year in just bricks-and-mortar, not counting the investment in digital and a huge percentage of that is for customer care to expand our capacities there. And as I just said, I think that business grows open-ended. With Tesla, well, I observed where his service centers are and I think he's going to have to address it at some point. The idea that these cars don't need to go anywhere to do anything, I don't buy into. You can only do so much over the Internet with these vehicles, and then you got to have experts hands on and people want to be able to do that in a convenient, friendly way. So as his owner base gets larger and as he wants bigger volume, I think he's going to need a different strategy. But that's just my opinion, and for him to figure out. But as far as what he's doing is a complete revolution, revolution for auto retail that's going to change everything, I don't buy that at all.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from David Whiston with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our final question comes from David Whiston with Morningstar.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, looking at the press release that your operating profit contribution by segment, it looks like there was a really nice uptick in the Domestic contribution at the expense of the other 2 segments. Yet on the same page, I'm seeing the F
componenttext: Two questions. First, looking at the press release that your operating profit contribution by segment, it looks like there was a really nice uptick in the Domestic contribution at the expense of the other 2 segments. Yet on the same page, I'm seeing the Ford new retail unit volume was down. So can you just flush out a bit what happened on the Domestic side that was positive to drive growth there?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: The drop in gasoline prices are a huge plus within the Domestic business. The American consumers have trucks on their mind. I assure you when the industry figures are finalized later today, I expect trucks to be over 55% of the mix, and they were trending
componenttext: The drop in gasoline prices are a huge plus within the Domestic business. The American consumers have trucks on their mind. I assure you when the industry figures are finalized later today, I expect trucks to be over 55% of the mix, and they were trending towards 45% of the mix 1.5 years, 2 years ago. So -- and let's face it, trucks are strength of the Domestic manufacturers. So that's a huge plus for them. Ford, at this moment, is caught in this huge change over, on the #1 selling vehicle in America for the last 36 years, the Ford F150. One plant is down, still, completely and the other plant is doing nicely, but they are literally in the midst of this changeover and if you look at the production schedules, I don't think we'll hit full availability on the F150 until May, until May. So their figures are going -- and our Ford figures are going to be impacted by that. The good news is, of the F150s that we received, we have customers waiting in line for them, they come in and go right out. There's no issues about the aluminum, they love the way it drives him, they love the towing capacity, they love the vehicle dynamics. So it's all good. But this is probably one of the biggest production changeovers ever attempted in industrial history. Ford's well in the way to executing it, but it's going to be May until we have full availability of this vehicle.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last question is on the AutoNation Express initiative. Once down the road, all the investment is done and your full operation across all of your stores nationwide, do you plan to do an extremely extensive advertising campaign, really, at a natio
componenttext: Okay. And last question is on the AutoNation Express initiative. Once down the road, all the investment is done and your full operation across all of your stores nationwide, do you plan to do an extremely extensive advertising campaign, really, at a national level to get the word out that shopping at AutoNation is not like going to other dealers?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we've already started the campaign in South Florida on the first capability of AutoNation Express. It's up and running. And as we move to other markets, we will begin marketing AutoNation Express. And as the capabilities expand, we will begin to advert
componenttext: So we've already started the campaign in South Florida on the first capability of AutoNation Express. It's up and running. And as we move to other markets, we will begin marketing AutoNation Express. And as the capabilities expand, we will begin to advertise the new features that are available to consumers. And again, here's how the way to think about it. I'm going to take all that money we're spending with third-party lead providers and shift it over to advertising AutoNation and AutoNation Express. And this, overtime, gives us a much stronger position in the marketplace. That's the power of what's behind this idea, this concept, this strategy. And I'm very much optimistic that I'll succeed, but to your point, it's already up and running. We're already advertising in our market, South Florida. We can put the commercials up on our website so that you could go there and see them. Now we run the campaign for the markets that we're in with the capabilities as they go online. There's not a national ad idea, we would need a national footprint, so it's very much focused with the markets that we're in. And as we move into new markets, then, of course, we would roll into new markets.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So something really extreme like a Super Bowl ad down the road is probably not on the table?
componenttext: So something really extreme like a Super Bowl ad down the road is probably not on the table?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Super Bowl ad is not on the table. Again, I have to make the point. We think bricks and mortar is extremely relevant. What happens within the bricks and mortar is changing dramatically. And so we only own brick and mortar in our footprint. And so it's an
componenttext: Super Bowl ad is not on the table. Again, I have to make the point. We think bricks and mortar is extremely relevant. What happens within the bricks and mortar is changing dramatically. And so we only own brick and mortar in our footprint. And so it's an integrated solution between owning the entire experience from the website right through the process in the store. That's our concept. And we would -- it's far in the future that AutoNation will be doing an AutoNation ad. I'm not even going to speculate on a date. Thank you, everyone, for joining us today.
