componenttext:
Welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have an objection, you may disconnect at this time. 
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Andrew Wamser, Treasurer and Vice President of Investor Relations for AutoNation. Sir, you may begin.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call and Webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill Berman, our Chief Ope
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's Second Quarter 2015 Conference Call and Webcast. 
Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill Berman, our Chief Operating Officer; and Jon Ferrando, our EVP responsible for M&A. 
Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Robert Quartaro and I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have. 
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments. Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from such forward-looking statements. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our press release issued earlier today and our SEC filings, including our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules will be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release and on our website located at investors.autonation.com. 
And now, I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman, CEO and President, Mike Jackson. Mike?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported record second quarter earnings per share from continuing operations of $1, a 20% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $0.83 for the same period in the prior year. This is
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported record second quarter earnings per share from continuing operations of $1, a 20% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $0.83 for the same period in the prior year. This is the 19th consecutive quarter of double-digit year-over-year growth and EPS from continuing operations. 
Second quarter 2015 revenue totaled $5.2 billion compared to $4.8 billion in the year ago period, an increase of 9%, driven by stronger performance in all our business sectors. Total gross profit was an all-time record at $819 million compared to $745 million in the year ago period, an increase of 10%. 
Operating income was a second quarter record at $220 million compared to $198 million in the year ago period, an increase of 12%. 
In the second quarter, AutoNation's retail new vehicle unit sales increased by 6% or 4% on the same-store sales basis. 
Last week, Financial [indiscernible], a Honda  financial services, announced a new policy for dealer reserve. It does not affect the dealer economics but achieves the CFPB's goal of reducing dealer reserve discretion. We have applaud Honda Financial Services for developing an enlightened solution that could become a template for the industry. 
Regarding our digital initiatives. We have accelerated the rollout of AutoNation Express. The first phase of rollout identifying and reserving a specific vehicle online has been well received by the marketplace and our associates. AutoNation expresses and  encompasses our continued commitment to delivering a peerless customer experience. 
I'll now turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer, Cheryl Miller.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the second quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $115 million or $1 per share versus net income of $101 million or $0.83 per share during the second quarter of 2014, a
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. 
For the second quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $115 million or $1 per share versus net income of $101 million or $0.83 per share during the second quarter of 2014, a 20% improvement on a per share basis. There were no adjustment to net income in either periods. 
In the second quarter, revenue increased $436 million or 9% compared to the prior year and gross profit improved $74 million or 10%. SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 69.4% for the quarter, which represents a 100 basis-point decrease compared to the year ago period. 
Net new vehicle floorplan was a benefit of $16 million, an increase of $2 million from the second quarter of 2014 primarily due to higher floorplan assistance. Floorplan assistance increased due to higher new vehicle sales and an increase in the floorplan assistance rate per unit. 
Floorplan debt increased sequentially, approximately $319 million during the second quarter to $3.3 billion at quarter end, primarily due to increased borrowings in our new and used floorplan facilities, which was driven by higher inventory levels supporting current sales trends and newly-acquired stores. 
Nonvehicle interest expense increased slightly to $21.6 million compared to $21.3 million the second quarter of 2014 due to higher debt balances. At the end of June, we had $2.1 billion of nonvehicle debt, an increase of $73 million compared to March 31, 2015. 
In addition to our fixed-rate debt, this balance includes $800 million of outstanding borrowings under the revolving credit facility and $299 million of commercial paper.  The provision for income tax in the quarter was $71.6 million or 38.3%. 
During the second quarter 2015, we repurchased 796,000 shares for $50 million at an average price of $62.78 per share. AutoNation has approximately $217 million of remaining board authorization for share repurchase. 
As of July 20, there were approximately 113 million shares outstanding, and, again, this does not include the dilutive impact of stock options. 
Our leverage ratio remained at 2.2x at the end of Q2 as compared to Q1. The leverage ratio was 2.0x on a net debt basis, including used floorplan availability and our covenant limit is 3.75x. 
Capital expenditures were $65.2 million for the quarter. Capital expenditures are on an accrual basis, excluding operating lease buyouts and related asset sales. 
Our quarter end cash balance was $65 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity, resulted in total liquidity of $1.1 billion at the end of June. We plan to use the revolving credit facility as liquidity backstop for borrowings under our commercial paper program. 
At quarter end, we had $299 million of commercial paper notes outstanding, which an effect reduces our available liquidity to $806 million. 
We remain committed to driving company value and shareholder returns through disciplined capital allocation as we continue to invest in strategic digital initiatives, acquisitions and opportunistic share repurchase. 
Now let me turn it over to our Chief Operating Officer, Bill Berman.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cheryl, and good morning. AutoNation posted record second quarter results with growth across all business sectors. We reported an all time record in total gross profits, used vehicle revenue, customer care revenue and customer care gross prof
componenttext:
Thank you, Cheryl, and good morning. 
AutoNation posted record second quarter results with growth across all business sectors. We reported an all time record in total gross profits, used vehicle revenue, customer care revenue and customer care gross profit. 
In the second quarter, we set records in operating income, net income from continuing operations and this marks our 19th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth. 
Going forward, my comments will be in the same-store basis and compared to the period a year ago unless noted otherwise. 
Total gross profit for variable operations was $459 million, up 6%. Total variable growth was $3307 on a per vehicle retail basis, an increase of $30 or 1%. New and used the same-store sale unit volume was up 5%. 
New vehicle growth revenue for the quarter was $2.9 billion, an increase of $144 million or 5%. We retailed 83,000 units, an increase of 4%. New vehicle gross profit was $1905 on a per vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $106 or 5%. 
We continue to experience new car PVR pressure in the Import segment, increased tenant as well as growth in entry-level Premium Luxury models. However, our focus remains on the total variable operations. 
For the quarter, used vehicle retail revenue was $1.1 billion, an increase of $86 million or 9% compared to the period a year ago. Used vehicle retail were 55,800, up 7%. Used vehicle gross profit was $1,590 on a per vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $95 or 6%. 
Customer financial services growth profit was $1,520 on a per vehicle retail basis, an increase of $133 or 10%. Approximately 2/3 of our gross profit per vehicle retailed was related to customer financial service product and 1/3 was related to finance. 
Total gross profit for customer financial services of $212 million was up $28 million or 15% compared to the period a year ago. 
During the quarter, we rolled out the first AutoNation branded products, the AutoNation Vehicle Protection Plan or VPP in our central region. The initial launch of VPP has been well received by our associates in the marketplace. 
By the end of the third quarter, the program will roll out nationwide through our meeting Domestic and Import stores. 
Over the remainder of the year, we will also pilot additional AutoNation branded products. We continue to see opportunity to customer financial services as we drive store-level execution and offer product to deliver customer value and drive loyalty. 
As Mike mentioned earlier, we do not expect the financial impact to our business from Honda Financial Services, new dealer reserve policy. The new policy provides compensation in addition to the dealer reserve which is capped to 100 to 125 basis points based on the term of the loan. We believe Honda's new policy could become attractive template for the industry. 
In the quarter, customer care revenue was an all-time record of $751 million, an increase of $51 million or 7%. We set another all-time customer in customer care and gross profit of $324 million, an increase of $26 million or 9%. 
Customer pay gross was $129 million, up 8%, our 20th consecutive quarterly increase in customer pay gross. 
Warranty gross was $62 million, up 11%. Collision gross was $30 million, up 12%. 
Turning to digital. Though we're still in the early phases of the rollout, we're pleased with the growth of traffic to our website. AutoNation's website generate over 20% of sales for the first half of the year. We completed the first phase of AutoNation Express 6 months ahead of schedule. 
We remain committed to providing transparency and delivering a peerless customer experience initiatives such as AutoNation Express. 
Thanks to the efforts of our 25,000 associates, we achieved an unprecedented milestone in automotive history with the sale of our 10 million vehicle. We continue to build on this momentum I the second half of the year by selling and servicing one car at a time to our next milestone. 
I'll now turn the call back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. We believe the auto industry remains healthy, and we're reconfirming our 2015 sales forecast of 17 million units. With that, we'll be happy to take your questions. I'm calling in from New York, so I'll direct the traffic on the question to
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. We believe the auto industry remains healthy, and we're reconfirming our 2015 sales forecast of 17 million units. 
With that, we'll be happy to take your questions. I'm calling in from New York, so I'll direct the traffic on the question to the team in Fort Lauderdale, but let's begin.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is Mr. Colin Langan of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is Mr. Colin Langan of UBS.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give color on the -- when you mentioned Honda's finance has no impact on your profit, you also made a comment that there's additional income in addition to the cap. How does that mechanism work?
componenttext: Can you give color on the -- when you mentioned Honda's finance has no impact on your profit, you also made a comment that there's additional income in addition to the cap. How does that mechanism work?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. I think the Honda agreement is very enlightened. It's something that, while in principle everyone agreed that discrimination or unintentional impact is not something that should exist in auto retail how to get there was quite a conte
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. I think the Honda agreement is very enlightened. It's something that, while in principle everyone agreed that discrimination or unintentional impact is not something that should exist in auto retail how to get there was quite a contentious dilemma. And I think the Honda solutions is quite enlightened in that by putting cash in place that dramatically reduced the amount of discretion that exists at the -- on the individual transaction at the store level is dramatically reduced. And in principle, AutoNation moved in that direction a decade ago. But with the capital only 100 to 125 basis points, the economics would change, and that's not acceptable as a solution and everyone agreed. CFPB lenders and certainly retailers that the added value that dealers have on indirect lending is significant and that the compensation we were receiving was fair and justified, and this was not about changing that. So there is additional compensation system that comes to the dealers for having originated the loan that is built into the base rate from Honda. So we've looked at it. We say that this kept us hold back to where we are and addresses CFPB issues. And I think it's workable for the lenders. So AutoNation is publicly supporting this direction. We will work with Honda closely on working out any bugs in the system to make sure we achieve this goal. And we will urge other lenders to take a close look at this as a template for a solution and pledge to those lenders if they go in this direction, they will have AutoNation's full support.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, I believe industry data says that there's about 100 basis point market on new but about 200 on used. So do you think there be separate rules for use or an adjustment made? Or is that a risk to the F&I profit?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, I believe industry data says that there's about 100 basis point market on new but about 200 on used. So do you think there be separate rules for use or an adjustment made? Or is that a risk to the F&I profit?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Honda is in the midst of having a series of meetings across the country where they're rolling this out. I think there are detailed questions that there still unanswered and there could be some changes. So I don't want to get too deep into the lead on e
componenttext: So Honda is in the midst of having a series of meetings across the country where they're rolling this out. I think there are detailed questions that there still unanswered and there could be some changes. So I don't want to get too deep into the lead on exactly how it all is going to work, but I can tell you, I've looked at it, I spoke with Honda, I spoke with CFPB. I believe this is a very workable concept and a structure. And with a little movement here in there, some details, it's going to work.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. One last question, just any color on the defined and what was driving the defined on the margin on new?
componenttext: Okay. One last question, just any color on the defined and what was driving the defined on the margin on new?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, it's Mike Jackson, again. I think, again, gas prices are significantly different what everyone thought they would be a couple years ago, so this has led to a tremendous shift in consumer demand. If you look at the year-to-date industry sales figu
componenttext: I think, it's Mike Jackson, again. I think, again, gas prices are significantly different what everyone thought they would be a couple years ago, so this has led to a tremendous shift in consumer demand. If you look at the year-to-date industry sales figures up 4.4%, that's 10% in trucks, 9% in luxury vehicles and car sales are, actually, down. There's a mishmash between installed capacity and what the marketplace is demanding. So there's quite a bit of pressure about -- around mid-sized sedans, which is a traditional strength of Japanese manufacturers. So that's a challenge. These things happen from time to time. We'll work through it, but that's what's going on. Bill, would you like to add any more color to that?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike the only thing I'd add is there some additional pressure coming from stair steps coming from certain manufacturers as well as entry-level Premium Luxury vehicles are having the adverse effect on PVR. But like I said earlier, we're looking at tot
componenttext: Yes, Mike the only thing I'd add is there some additional pressure coming from stair steps coming from certain manufacturers as well as entry-level Premium Luxury vehicles are having the adverse effect on PVR. But like I said earlier, we're looking at total variable TBR and for the seventh consecutive quarter, we're going to grow that and last quarter was additional $30.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. John Murphy of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. John Murphy of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question, it sounds like the AutoNation Express and your online efforts have been really pulled forward an accelerated here. I'm just curious how that correlates to your spending, your investment. You've highlighted on that and what kind of benefits
componenttext: First question, it sounds like the AutoNation Express and your online efforts have been really pulled forward an accelerated here. I'm just curious how that correlates to your spending, your investment. You've highlighted on that and what kind of benefits we might be able to see more quickly in the second half of this year and going into 2016?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So John, I think that's a correct assumption. And in our plan for this always have contingencies for challenges and difficulties that you can't foresee. In this case though, we saw the opportunities to move faster. And so we did, and I'm not going to quan
componenttext: So John, I think that's a correct assumption. And in our plan for this always have contingencies for challenges and difficulties that you can't foresee. In this case though, we saw the opportunities to move faster. And so we did, and I'm not going to quantify how much money that is, but we made additional investments in the second quarter. Also, as I laid out years ago that we would reduce our dependency on third parties and there would be a vetting process to determine who we could partner with in the long-term of third parties but that we expect to ultimately be in the high single digits. We came to a fork in the road with TrueCar, which is 3% of our business in the second quarter, and that money will be reinvested in the AutoNation brand and AutoNation Express going forward. So it's strategically all good news. I think we are on the right path for our company. I'm absolutely convinced of it. But we need the flexibility and freedom depending on circumstances to either speed up or slow down depending what we're confronted with. But we're very pleased and I have to congratulate Bill and his team for fully implementing AutoNation Express first phase 6 months ahead of time, it's quite an effort.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And does that mean that the bulk of the $100 million has been spent? Or is that still over the next couple of years that would -- there's still a big chunk to come over the next couple of years?
componenttext: Okay. And does that mean that the bulk of the $100 million has been spent? Or is that still over the next couple of years that would -- there's still a big chunk to come over the next couple of years?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's still -- far to go, John. So phase one, the next phase that will take out nationally is we'll buy your car, that's already through pilot that will roll out the rest of this year. And then we'll be in pilot phase towards the end of the year for fin
componenttext: There's still -- far to go, John. So phase one, the next phase that will take out nationally is we'll buy your car, that's already through pilot that will roll out the rest of this year. And then we'll be in pilot phase towards the end of the year for financing and customer care and then move that out in 2016. We intend to fully make our site transactional for every phase of the business. And we think combined with our brand positioning to attract consumers to our site, give them a good experience, the most important thing is on site, they want to be able to do something, the sites need to be transactional. This combination of a strong brand with consumer empowered transactional sites, that is seamlessly integrated into the dealerships is something no one else in the industry is doing, and we're convinced it will be a significant competitive advantage for us in the long-term. And how we have to make those investments from quarter-to-quarter will speed up and slow down depending upon the challenges and opportunities that we have.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up on the question of the new vehicle gross pressure. I mean, is this really something where you think it is really just a mixed shift? Because there's a lot of concern in a market that portends some pressure on demand, in gen
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up on the question of the new vehicle gross pressure. I mean, is this really something where you think it is really just a mixed shift? Because there's a lot of concern in a market that portends some pressure on demand, in general. I mean, just curious on what you're seeing there. If you think demand is fundamentally showing up and not being incented by these cuts in gross.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way we think about it, John, and I was very clear with the team several years ago that total variable gross is our final report card. And we really have a lot of different ways to get there, but I want to see and the company wants to see it steady inc
componenttext: The way we think about it, John, and I was very clear with the team several years ago that total variable gross is our final report card. And we really have a lot of different ways to get there, but I want to see and the company wants to see it steady increase in total variable gross. And then how the various pieces move within that is interesting, and we'll talk about, but at the end of the day, we have to put the whole pie together where we've shown we are very successful in doing that. Front and grosses will move around new cars depending like we already spoke about, the gas situation, used cars this year, we're pushing for volume, but if you then take those opportunities and are able to package it with your financial services and products and come out ahead, I think it's a good business plan. And so we've consistently demonstrated the ability to do that. And so that's the big picture for me that I'm saying. I think our total front-end gross is stable to -- I observed the fact that second quarter in a row we've improved it so there's something going on there, and there it is.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, Cheryl, you alluded the floorplan assistance being increased and rates being increased. Just curious why that's happening with inventory levels largely balanced and demand coming through. I'm not sure why there would be an incr
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, Cheryl, you alluded the floorplan assistance being increased and rates being increased. Just curious why that's happening with inventory levels largely balanced and demand coming through. I'm not sure why there would be an increase in floorplan assistance coming from the automakers. Just curious why that happens.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Some of that is mix shift, so I would say that varies depending on what product is out there, what we have out there. Our book was within floorplan certainly is to make sure we're running the inventories in a disciplined way to take advantage of the assis
componenttext: Some of that is mix shift, so I would say that varies depending on what product is out there, what we have out there. Our book was within floorplan certainly is to make sure we're running the inventories in a disciplined way to take advantage of the assistance per unit, but also to keep down the interest expense cost. So we're very focused on our partnership with the bank lenders on the interest expense side as well as making sure we manage the inventory there as well. But as you know, the OEMs have an ability to look at that assistance per unit, and that's something that as interest rates move up, which at some point, they will, so whether that's September, December or into next year, that's another variable that the OEM have that they can continue to look at.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's more of a mix than an actual rate change at this point, but there could be a rate change going forward, is what you're saying?
componenttext: Okay. So it's more of a mix than an actual rate change at this point, but there could be a rate change going forward, is what you're saying?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll say [indiscernible] some of them have moved it per unit, some of it is mixed and then I think going forward, it's something that we'll continue to see how the OEM evaluate that, particularly in a rising rate environment in the future.
componenttext: I'll say [indiscernible] some of them have moved it per unit, some of it is mixed and then I think going forward, it's something that we'll continue to see how the OEM evaluate that, particularly in a rising rate environment in the future.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is Paresh Jain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A follow-up on the CFPB impact. Now, Mike, AutoNation has certainly welcoming the Honda solution, but there seems to be still a lot of assistance in the broader dealer. So if I'm looking at it from a different angle, any potential negative impact here per
componenttext: A follow-up on the CFPB impact. Now, Mike, AutoNation has certainly welcoming the Honda solution, but there seems to be still a lot of assistance in the broader dealer. So if I'm looking at it from a different angle, any potential negative impact here perhaps could be far worse from a smaller dealer groups that on an average have 1 or 2 stores. And don't have the same levels to pull as AutoNation and other big dealer groups to offset that impact. So do you think this could hurt the multiple and create some acquisition opportunities since a lot of times valuation is what holds up deals from getting done?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think in principle, you would have a point and while this is still very controversial within the total dealer organization, and you saw both NADA and AIADA come out with strong statements opposing this. I think for smaller dealers, the ever-increasin
componenttext: So I think in principle, you would have a point and while this is still very controversial within the total dealer organization, and you saw both NADA and AIADA come out with strong statements opposing this. I think for smaller dealers, the ever-increasing regulatory burden in principle. And by the way, you can look at that for all business, whether we're talking about how you keep track of overtime, how you deal with health care, the regulatory environment now here around the CFPB, it's a regulatory burden for smaller companies, in principle, in America, it's getting more and more difficult. And also there is a large number of dealers who have not narrowed their bandwidth on their financing reserves, had not installed disciplined caps. And so they have much further to go to get to a solution like Honda. Now I can't begin to tell you whether that's going to change the acquisition environment. I will tell you though that this regulatory burden and difficulty of doing business and the complexity of the demands from the OEMs, you need a Ph.D. to keep track of these incentive programs. It's making the world much more difficult than you need a certain size and a certain structure and a certain discipline to be able to manage it all. So I think the willing sellers are going to be standing there for quite some time.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That make sense. And then on AutoNation Express, and I apologize if I have missed this earlier, I understand you may not be able to share specific numbers on the performance impact. But can you highlight certain metrics that you internally tracking? Is it
componenttext: That make sense. And then on AutoNation Express, and I apologize if I have missed this earlier, I understand you may not be able to share specific numbers on the performance impact. But can you highlight certain metrics that you internally tracking? Is it about conversion, is it about transaction time, market share? Just wanted to understand how you prioritize and rank your goals with express initiative.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it's a 1, 2 punch, and that cannot be missed. First, we're building the brand, AutoNation, and the metric I can give you there is that the awareness and consideration we're doing business with AutoNation in a relatively short period of time, just over
componenttext: So it's a 1, 2 punch, and that cannot be missed. First, we're building the brand, AutoNation, and the metric I can give you there is that the awareness and consideration we're doing business with AutoNation in a relatively short period of time, just over 2 years, has already exceeded all the legacy brands. It's just a tremendous launch and embraced by the marketplace. The next metric we look at, and we've changed our marketing to drive much more traffic to AutoNation sites is what is the yield, or what is the business generated from AutoNation sites by raising the visibility of our brand in all the ways you do in the digital marketplace and then how do you prove the experience that you have ever higher customer satisfaction, higher closing rates. And again, I'll just give you their very broad metrics from -- before we started this effort, AutoNation's digital sites generated less than 10% of the business, and now, we're over 20% of the business. So that's a doubling since the brand launch and the investments to improve experience on the AutoNation sites. So if you look at that report card, you say, this is working.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And lastly, just a housekeeping one. Depreciation kind of saw an uptick this quarter. What was the driver for that? And how sustainable is it?
componenttext: Got it. And lastly, just a housekeeping one. Depreciation kind of saw an uptick this quarter. What was the driver for that? And how sustainable is it?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That would be Cheryl's specialty. Cheryl?
componenttext: That would be Cheryl's specialty. Cheryl?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct. This is Cheryl. Welcome to the call. The majority of the increase is actually driven by recent renovations and acquisition as well as accelerated depreciation on a corporate asset. But going forward, we expect depreciation will be more in line wi
componenttext: Correct. This is Cheryl. Welcome to the call. The majority of the increase is actually driven by recent renovations and acquisition as well as accelerated depreciation on a corporate asset. But going forward, we expect depreciation will be more in line with Q1 of '15. And keep in mind that on digital, the majority of digital is actually spent, so we're pleased with our ability to keep SG&A as a percentage of growth improving versus last year and below that 70% metric despite the increase in the investment.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Mr. David Lim of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is Mr. David Lim of Wells Fargo.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to, again, follow-up on the gross margin question, but on a yearly basis we've seen declines since 2012. I guess, the question is, what are the factors that can possibly turn that around where we can see some incremental gains coming into the fut
componenttext: I wanted to, again, follow-up on the gross margin question, but on a yearly basis we've seen declines since 2012. I guess, the question is, what are the factors that can possibly turn that around where we can see some incremental gains coming into the future? I mean, you've talked about mix and some stairstep programs, but what would actually turn the industry around for you guys?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You can get cadence launches from manufacturers, particularly in Premium Luxury where certain products when they arrived for the first year or 2 can actually impact the entire margin of the company. So they're nice to have, but it's incidental and you can
componenttext: You can get cadence launches from manufacturers, particularly in Premium Luxury where certain products when they arrived for the first year or 2 can actually impact the entire margin of the company. So they're nice to have, but it's incidental and you can say that's a strategic shift. I would say, in principle, the pressure on front end margins I expect to remain. It's a competitive marketplace. You have -- stairs steps are being embraced by additional marketing companies, and that is a downward pressure. And you have pressure from third-party -- from certain third-party sites that put pressure on front end margins. So it's a very competitive marketplace. So I am not calling a turn in the front end gross margin. If it happens, we're certainly point it out when it does, but I'm not sitting here looking forward, at an environment where I say, I see how we can do that, not that we aren't trying, but I'm not predicting it, and that's why couple of years ago, we said, look, we've got -- we really got to have a strategy that we look at the total front-end variable gross on the transaction, and we've implemented that strategy, and we're executing it successfully.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. The question -- the follow up question I have there is are you seeing additional OEMs? I think you alluded to this additional OEMs offering stairs steps. And also, is a larger percentage of sales for you as well as an industry really relying upon
componenttext: Got you. The question -- the follow up question I have there is are you seeing additional OEMs? I think you alluded to this additional OEMs offering stairs steps. And also, is a larger percentage of sales for you as well as an industry really relying upon the leases on these? And if so, are you seeing OEMs playing with the residual values when they come to the lease calculation?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as far as stairs steps, I sort of come to terms that there's no free certainties, debt, taxes and stair steps. I've railed against them and all theirs since, but they're not going away. And you have some practitioners who have gotten highly skilled at
componenttext: So as far as stairs steps, I sort of come to terms that there's no free certainties, debt, taxes and stair steps. I've railed against them and all theirs since, but they're not going away. And you have some practitioners who have gotten highly skilled at it even though I don't like to practice, they, actually, run it in a very professional way, and you have others where it's absolutely a loose cannon rolling back and forth across the deck, and you have a couple new comers to the party. So there it is, I don't think they're going away. And leasing, we like leasing. I have no issues with leasing. I think Auto financing, whether it's longer term leasing is in fantastic shape. People pay for their cars, the record is clear and leasing does set up a recurring buying cycle which is very worthwhile. Bill, do you have anything to add?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would add our leasing penetration have gone up slightly about 200 basis point on a year-over-year basis. Like Mike said, I'm a big fan of leasing and there doesn't appear to be any really incentivization of money -- sorry, of the residuals. They're
componenttext: Yes, I would add our leasing penetration have gone up slightly about 200 basis point on a year-over-year basis. Like Mike said, I'm a big fan of leasing and there doesn't appear to be any really incentivization of money -- sorry, of the residuals. They're pretty on-base to the industry standards. Most of it is coming on the finance side of leasing, so we don't  see any real impact when it comes to kind of overhead on residual values.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Just 2 more questions quickly. We noticed that your inventories had a little uptick on a quarter-over-quarter basis. I think some of that was explained, but I was wondering if you can give additional color. And then finally, when you talk about the
componenttext: Great. Just 2 more questions quickly. We noticed that your inventories had a little uptick on a quarter-over-quarter basis. I think some of that was explained, but I was wondering if you can give additional color. And then finally, when you talk about the Honda settlement, I think you were alluding to the fact that Honda would give some sort of fees or its stake than to the original cost of loan. But if we strip all of that out, would it go back to, let's say, 150 or 200 basis points above when it comes to dealer reserve?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well on Honda, I don't understand the question. So there is compensation in the base by rate that is going to come to the retailer, and then we have a range of markup of 100 to 125 basis points depending on term. And we will put both that compensation int
componenttext: Well on Honda, I don't understand the question. So there is compensation in the base by rate that is going to come to the retailer, and then we have a range of markup of 100 to 125 basis points depending on term. And we will put both that compensation into dealer reserve as you refer to it. And when you combine both, we come out at the same place that we are today. That's the easiest way I can explain it.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. So I was trying to understand is that same place, is that like 200 bps in the old methodology? Or how [indiscernible].
componenttext: Got you. So I was trying to understand is that same place, is that like 200 bps in the old methodology? Or how [indiscernible].

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's interesting. So our old caps were 250 basis points, the old system that we're operating under and our average dealer reserve is 90 basis points.
componenttext: It's interesting. So our old caps were 250 basis points, the old system that we're operating under and our average dealer reserve is 90 basis points.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And can you talk about...
componenttext: Got you. And can you talk about...

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, you talk about the inventories, please?
componenttext: Bill, you talk about the inventories, please?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the inventory is being ramped up two things, first and foremost driven by acquisitions from last year, obviously, intrinsically, that brings up the inventory as well as increased inventory going into the selling season. So we have no issues on the da
componenttext: Yes, the inventory is being ramped up two things, first and foremost driven by acquisitions from last year, obviously, intrinsically, that brings up the inventory as well as increased inventory going into the selling season. So we have no issues on the day supply or by any particular brand.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Mr. Rick Nelson of Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question is Mr. Rick Nelson of Stephens.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, can you address the TrueCar situation, what you think is happening in that business?
componenttext: Mike, can you address the TrueCar situation, what you think is happening in that business?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So TrueCar generate -- the leads generated 3% of our business. We were operating under a contract that had acceptable terms. That contract expired end of February, beginning of March. TrueCar had demanded and the new contract that we give them, all our cu
componenttext: So TrueCar generate -- the leads generated 3% of our business. We were operating under a contract that had acceptable terms. That contract expired end of February, beginning of March. TrueCar had demanded and the new contract that we give them, all our customer information. In all contract, we gave TrueCar no customer information, we gave them anonymous data, but we gave them no customer information. This is an unprecedented demand. They weren't asking for the 3%, they were asking for 100%, and we've never given -- I don't know what company gives away 100% of their customer information. I think also if we said yes, definitely would have created privacy issues that would have been cumbersome for us to implement and that we would have to gotten permission from our customers to give this information to TrueCar, and we really didn't want to intrude into a sales transaction by saying, oh Mr. Smith, you've never heard of TrueCar? But do you mind if we saw them all of the information on this transaction? That's something we really wanted to protect the privacy of our customers. And TrueCar was making this demand saying this is how they operate with all their dealerships. And while I certainly didn't investigate that other than to say, I don't think that's true. I don't think they operate quite differently with other companies. I think this is a new demand that we cannot agree to. So I think it was a demand that we could not agree to was based on a false premise. And if you arrive at that point the company, you should really just go your separate ways. That's what we've done. We think our brand is strong enough, our digital capabilities are strong enough that we would be fine. And TrueCar is now on our rearview mirror.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay so you upset volume by reallocating spend to drive volume that's where?
componenttext: Okay so you upset volume by reallocating spend to drive volume that's where?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I thought I would be at this point years ago that at some point a third-party would make a demand that was unacceptable, was an overreach. And we better have a way to go when that day comes our else you're really in trouble. So I believe our brand and our
componenttext: I thought I would be at this point years ago that at some point a third-party would make a demand that was unacceptable, was an overreach. And we better have a way to go when that day comes our else you're really in trouble. So I believe our brand and our digital effort is strong enough that we will be able to go forward and put TrueCar in the rearview mirror.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I'd also have Bill try to reach overall performance and strengths, weaknesses and particularly Texas, Florida, California. If there's any outliers there.
componenttext: Great. I'd also have Bill try to reach overall performance and strengths, weaknesses and particularly Texas, Florida, California. If there's any outliers there.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Rick, this is Bill. Actually, we had strong performance out of all 3 states that you just called out: Texas Florida and California. We had no negative impact in Texas with declining oil prices, if anything, it put disposable income into our consumer
componenttext: Okay, Rick, this is Bill. Actually, we had strong performance out of all 3 states that you just called out: Texas Florida and California. We had no negative impact in Texas with declining oil prices, if anything, it put disposable income into our consumers' hand and we have very solid growth out of all 3 of those markets. And across the country, all 3 of our regions are performing at a very high-level and pretty much across the board.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is Mr. Brett Hoselton of KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question is Mr. Brett Hoselton of KeyBanc.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions. First of all, M&A outlook, have you seen any notable immaterial changes may be in terms of the volume of deals and our valuations?
componenttext: Two quick questions. First of all, M&A outlook, have you seen any notable immaterial changes may be in terms of the volume of deals and our valuations?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, could you first take care of that?
componenttext: John, could you first take care of that?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brett, it's Jon Ferrando. We've been pretty consistent that couple of years in calling out that we're expecting big potential opportunities the next few years. We have been able to execute on that with over $2 billion of annualized revenue acquired since
componenttext: Brett, it's Jon Ferrando. We've been pretty consistent that couple of years in calling out that we're expecting big potential opportunities the next few years. We have been able to execute on that with over $2 billion of annualized revenue acquired since late 2012. Through the first 6 months of this year, we've closed 5 acquisitions with $320 million in revenue. It's a good brand mix, including Premium Luxury so we feel like we been able to execute on opportunities in the marketplace. I would say, currently, we continue to see a solid, strong pipeline of potential deals out there, and we are well positioned for a number of reasons to continue to execute on acquisitions that will provide a strong return on capital. So we'll continue to be prudent. We see good opportunities, and we're well positioned to execute.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And switching gears, as we look out over the next year or 2, interest rates are likely to rise. My question is simply, how do we think about the impact of interest rates on your earnings? In other words, what are maybe some of the more significant impact,
componenttext: And switching gears, as we look out over the next year or 2, interest rates are likely to rise. My question is simply, how do we think about the impact of interest rates on your earnings? In other words, what are maybe some of the more significant impact, areas of impact on your earnings?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we fully -- it's Mike Jackson. We fully expect interest rates to begin rising later this year. It will be different than most interest rate increase cycles in that it would go slower and stop sooner, that's what we expect. We think that's entirely m
componenttext: Well, we fully -- it's Mike Jackson. We fully expect interest rates to begin rising later this year. It will be different than most interest rate increase cycles in that it would go slower and stop sooner, that's what we expect. We think that's entirely manageable. And you can't expect these extremely low interest rates forever, and it could, actually, be a very healthy sign for the economy that you're telling everyone, this crisis is over. And I think we will go on selling high 16 million, 17 million vehicles in a more normal interest rate environment. Inflation appears to be far away, so above-average rates are something over the horizon from this point of view. As far as to quantify exactly what the cost is of 100 basis points, do you have that Cheryl?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would note there's a couple of places that impact us. If you think about from a customer perspective, for instance, if you have a 1% increase in interest rate, that's less than $15 a month. On the average 30,000, 60 months lens. We always think fir
componenttext: Yes, I would note there's a couple of places that impact us. If you think about from a customer perspective, for instance, if you have a 1% increase in interest rate, that's less than $15 a month. On the average 30,000, 60 months lens. We always think first about impacting customer. And as Mike said in a slow steady rise, that can be very manageable. We've got $2.1 billion of corporate debt, that's 56 splitting and then we've got $3.3 billion of floorplans, which flows but to John's point earlier discussion that we had, you have the assistance of that, you can manage inventory levels you can see where the OEMs go over that fixed-rate assistance on a per vehicle basis to help offset that. The underlying theme though -- this a cyclical business, we've been through interest rate cycles and rises before, we think it's manageable. We think usually the customer is -- tends to be better positioned, which is part of why the rates are rising. And overall, for the economy, we think it's a healthy thing, we're prepared for it. An example of the things that we do in light of it is commercial paper program. So we were able to secure $300 million of financing at a market rate, which are substantially lower than our revolver. So we're looking for ways to continue to reduce spreads and look at alternative instruments where possible to help lower blended rate where we can. And I think that's a great thing about a strong balance sheet is the ability to make sure that we're hitting pockets of the market. There's a lot of capital out there, so we're going to hit pockets of the market where we can be flexible and opportunistic at lower cost rates.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, you've been ahead of a lot of industry trends over the course of the last decade. And, I guess, I just want to potentially peel back the onion on why you think we have another 2 to 3 years of $16.5 million to $17 million SAAR and, I guess, I'll just
componenttext: Mike, you've been ahead of a lot of industry trends over the course of the last decade. And, I guess, I just want to potentially peel back the onion on why you think we have another 2 to 3 years of $16.5 million to $17 million SAAR and, I guess, I'll just take it there?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've seen the argument for $18 million, $19 million, I've seen the argument for $14 million, $15 million. I don't believe either of those, I think it's high $16 million, $17 million is trend. I think the average age is still pushed out to 11.5, 11.6 years
componenttext: I've seen the argument for $18 million, $19 million, I've seen the argument for $14 million, $15 million. I don't believe either of those, I think it's high $16 million, $17 million is trend. I think the average age is still pushed out to 11.5, 11.6 years. Interest rates are still going to be very reasonable for consumers. I've seen the product portfolio from the manufacturers, it's extraordinary, the best ever. And it looks like gas prices are going to be low for extended period of times. So it's hard to say anything past 3 years, but I think we still have several years to go of high 16, 17, and it's too far over the horizon to say how many. When will it end? When inflation rears its head and the Federal Reserve begins increasing interest rates above normal aggressively to tap down inflation, there will be the downturn in housing and there will be a downturn in auto sales. I am absolutely convinced Cheryl said it earlier, we remain in the cyclical business, and that is not going to change. We'll be prepared for it, we will outperform on it. If our stock falls out the significant favor during the period, we'll view it as buying opportunity. So we really have -- we really -- we can create shareholder value anywhere in the cycle, any time in the cycle, but I think it's high 16, 17. If you want us -- so we all can manage 18, 19, so let's not talk about that. Those who argue for '4, let's say, two things that car sharing is going to have a significant impact on the marketplace, I think car sharing has its place in the marketplace. I think it's wonderful. I think Uber is a great company, but just add up, there's 3 trillion miles driven a year in the United States, how many miles are driven on our car sharing. It's an indispensable part of the marketplace. It will have its place, but it's not going to structure really change the selling volume. And we have millenniums who are going to buy cars, that's the other argument, they're not going to get driver's license, they're not going to drive cars. We talk about the generation everyday. They have a student debt problem that they need to work off, it's a 4- to 5-year delay in what they normally would be doing and are thus, but they want their own, the want to get married, they want to have kids, and they want to have a car. And so that is going to become the biggest generation buying new vehicles in. And so I'm right smack there in the middle, high 16 -- high 17 million, high 16 million to 17 million I think that's sustainable over the next several years.

componenttext: I think it's way too far away. Again, I'm not in denial, I think -- and I think there's a role for car sharing especially in certain urban settings, and I think people, everyone is open to it. I mean, everyone has embraced over, is that urgent generational thing. It's a great way of doing things. But to say that it's going to take 3 million out of the annual selling rate of new vehicles, I just can't get there at all. So that's my point of view, and we'll see. So far, my batting average on these things is pretty good, so we'll see.

It is a large investment, it's 5 weeks of their time throughout a year along with mentorship along the way. So we're able to attract, retain, develop great talent through the investment. So we continue to expand our university development offerings to talent people that want to go further with their career.
