componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Jamie Albertine from Stifel.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask on the used retail side. Thank you for the additional color with respect to the recall campaign. If you could maybe tell us a little bit more or shed some more light on what the cadence of used vehicle sales would have looked like x th
componenttext: I was hoping to ask on the used retail side. Thank you for the additional color with respect to the recall campaign. If you could maybe tell us a little bit more or shed some more light on what the cadence of used vehicle sales would have looked like x that campaign. Is there any granularity you can provide?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Jackson. It's very difficult to say what the missed opportunity was, so I'm very -- I'm not enthusiastic about putting an actual number on there other than to say there was an opportunity impact. Obviously, our used vehicle sales were stable. We
componenttext: It's Mike Jackson. It's very difficult to say what the missed opportunity was, so I'm very -- I'm not enthusiastic about putting an actual number on there other than to say there was an opportunity impact. Obviously, our used vehicle sales were stable. We had some impact on the gross as it took longer to prepare vehicles, to have a frontline ready. And there is some disruption. But we think we're going to work through all those issues over the next quarter and starting sometime in the first half of next year go back to growing the used vehicle business and improving the grosses. There are -- there will be some permanent hard cost in that we're going to increase inventory to allow for on the used side 10% to 15% of it will be tied up at all times with open recall, but I think that cost is very manageable, you can do the math on that. The building, the technology systems to manage it all both to identify the open recalls every day and to manage the process, of getting them all repaired, that's all underway, that's again a manageable cost, and it's a onetime cost. But clearly, there is some opportunity that we missed in the quarter because of the steps that we've taken. In my view, it's hard to put a number on that, but if you weigh the cost benefit both for what it needs for the industry that we're taking a leadership position in something that's clearly a black eye for the industry at the moment, namely the recall situation that AutoNation is going to part of the solution, not part of the problem, that we put our customers first, the safety of our customers first is a clear brand statement. And we see that the strength of our brand is, every year, more evident. And all you have to do is look at on the new vehicle side where we pivoted away from dependence on traffic bought from third parties to relying on our brand and our own sites and investing in those, the strength that, that gave us to unique brand attribute like the recall policy to positioning in the marketplace that the company really cares about big issues such as the fight against cancer and right now the Drive Pink is focused on breast cancer awareness and raising funds to find a cure. I think all of this is very compelling. And so yes, in used cars, we have some lost opportunity for a few quarters, but in the grand scheme of things, I think we're on it convincing and compelling growth. Because the hardest thing to do in business is to open a sustainable competitive advantage. And I think the evidence is becoming clear and fear that AutoNation is doing something special.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color, and we would agree with the long-term outlook as well. If I may, along those same lines, just a quick follow-up. You talked about these in the last couple of years some spending around your digital initiatives, the coast-to-coast b
componenttext: I appreciate the color, and we would agree with the long-term outlook as well. If I may, along those same lines, just a quick follow-up. You talked about these in the last couple of years some spending around your digital initiatives, the coast-to-coast branding. It seems to us, just based on the data that you're providing, as it relates to lead generation and so forth, are those investments starting to leverage themselves? Just some additional color there would be great in terms of the returns you're seeing on those investments. And then, if at all, there are sort of further sort of supplementary investments that you're going to look to make in the near term that we should consider from our modeling?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the third quarter is the proof in the pudding. That's exactly what you described is happening on the digital side and the fact that if I just look at the new car business, which was primarily where Costco and TrueCar was, Joe, I think it was around 7
componenttext: Yes, the third quarter is the proof in the pudding. That's exactly what you described is happening on the digital side and the fact that if I just look at the new car business, which was primarily where Costco and TrueCar was, Joe, I think it was around 7% of our business, something like 7% of our new car business we walked away from and yet we had an outstanding performance. So if you want clear evidence to forward the brand is taking hold and that our -- the enhancement of our digital sides making better customer experience is worthwhile, and if you want -- to me, the biggest proof is look at our front-end gross new vehicles, up $33. So we walk -- the business we walked away from with TrueCar and Costco haven't have -- their front end gross on average was $900 less than the business coming through AutoNation channels. So we left our most unprofitable business behind us, our most expensive business to acquire. It weakens our brand, it did not strengthen our brand. That's why I think the third quarter is uncontestable proof that the strategy we've been talking about, investing in, has been validated, and that we're getting tremendous benefit from it. We have probably, on the pure technology side, passed the peak investment periods, but substantial investment is yet to come.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttextpreview: Just a first question on the recall policy. I mean, the flip side of this is that you're going to have potentially a greater capture of warranty here. And I'm just curious, have you thought about that sort of offset and how big an offset would that be to
componenttext: Just a first question on the recall policy. I mean, the flip side of this is that you're going to have potentially a greater capture of warranty here. And I'm just curious, have you thought about that sort of offset and how big an offset would that be to the cost of caring that inventory?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think the fact that we'll do all that work is true, but I don't -- I really don't think it begins to offset the length of time, additional length of time it takes to get used vehicles frontline ready. So it's more about the brand and more about be
componenttext: John, I think the fact that we'll do all that work is true, but I don't -- I really don't think it begins to offset the length of time, additional length of time it takes to get used vehicles frontline ready. So it's more about the brand and more about being part of the solution for an industry black eyed and the fact that we'll actually do more recall work. There is an issue out there floating that, if the new vehicle dealers in the United States are authorized and have the technical skill to make these repairs and completion rates are not acceptable, and you'll hear regulators talking about the fact, well, it the new vehicle dealers and the manufacturers can't figure out how to get these repairs done faster at a higher level, we're going to open it up to everyone else. And I think that would be not a good development on any side. And I, for one, believe when you have an issue in the industry, be part of the solution. If it's a genuine issue for our customers. The irony is, I think, most customers think the repairs are already done. So that's what's behind it. Yes, we will do additional recall work, but it really doesn't offset the disruption and the speed-to-market of our used vehicles.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Then a second question. I mean, obviously, you're in a large acquisition tier here, but you're also being reasonably aggressive at buying back shares. And it seems like, as a Cheryl you kind of outlined, you do have a fair amount of
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Then a second question. I mean, obviously, you're in a large acquisition tier here, but you're also being reasonably aggressive at buying back shares. And it seems like, as a Cheryl you kind of outlined, you do have a fair amount of capacity given your current companies to do a lot more. Just curious how you think about this capital allocation, either going forward with that much room and really that much opportunity. I mean, its inspector pressing the pedal a lot harder than you have in the past and you've done very good job in the past as well. But how much more opportunity you think there is in the future? Are we going to be looking at another $1.7 billion in acquired revenue over the next 12 months and another big share buyback in place? I mean, how far can you push this?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take it first, and then I'll turn it over to Cheryl. The one thing that's not changed in all of these is our threshold on returns, not remain the same. We look for acquisitions that are strategic fit for us, fit on our model where we want to be want
componenttext: I'll take it first, and then I'll turn it over to Cheryl. The one thing that's not changed in all of these is our threshold on returns, not remain the same. We look for acquisitions that are strategic fit for us, fit on our model where we want to be want 1/3, Domestic; 1/3, Asian; 1/3, German. And our cultural fit with our company and certainly, these acquisitions are cultural fit. Sometimes, there is a difference in point of view about the future of certain company. I, for one, I'm very optimistic and confident about the team at Chrysler. So I have no hesitation buying big on Chrysler, I'm all in. And so you'll see some time a streak like that come long. Now, as I said before, when we look at 100 deals, we may be due 10. So there's a lot of discussions, a lot of conversations going on in and it has to meet all the structural to make that. We have a lot of conversation that we could do a lot of deals next year whether they'll meet all that criteria or not, I don't know. And what I very much like is keeping the flexibility that I can do 0 next year or I can do $2 billion next year. I'm not going to get myself -- down myself to a cross on that, it really is dependent. The same thing on share repurchase, it's opportunistic. If the opportunity is there on both share acquisitions and acquisition, am I comfortable with a higher level of leverage? Absolutely. Cheryl, why don't you talk about that?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, one of the things I would point out here, acquisition come with EBITDA. So when we think about, just as we said earlier, as we look at balanced approach so the stock where the market favorable will buy opportunistically. If the acquisition mark
componenttext: Yes, John, one of the things I would point out here, acquisition come with EBITDA. So when we think about, just as we said earlier, as we look at balanced approach so the stock where the market favorable will buy opportunistically. If the acquisition market is strong, we'll buy. We wont shape acquisition, so I think if you rollback 2 years ago, we were patient, we were looking primarily for good dealership that fit our existing footprint or platforms in other areas that might be a good fit for us, right? So we've stayed discipline. We haven't shaved things internationally. We continue to spend the nice thing as we're starting to see some deals hit, and we've been positioned for this. So with the strength in our base cash operating business, combined with EBITDA we get with the acquisitions knowing that acquisition will increase EBITDA, it gives us a lot of flexibility to do both. I think we're in a great situation from a liquidity standpoint and from a leverage standpoint, this balanced approach gives you an opportunity where some of the capital allocation actually comes with accretive EBITDA as well.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And John, one more factor that you have to put in there today versus the past is the strength of the brand, AutoNation. So think about it. So we buy the Allen Samuels group in Texas. Great name, fine, everything. We are going to rebrand those stores AutoN
componenttext: And John, one more factor that you have to put in there today versus the past is the strength of the brand, AutoNation. So think about it. So we buy the Allen Samuels group in Texas. Great name, fine, everything. We are going to rebrand those stores AutoNation. And as good as the legacy names are, so not as good as the brand name AutoNation and all the attributes that come with it. Also, we take all the marketing communication moneys that are being spent by the Allen Samuels group. Not to save, but the put behind the AutoNation name. So then our whole presence in the State of Texas goes up by another factor. And it begins to feed on itself, and therefore, our confidence that we can execute on our plan to hit our return and the amount of risk involved, the risk goes down and the confidence goes up, all because of the brand AutoNation. That's what a brand is doing for us at this point. Also, sellers, really, like to talk to AutoNation. They've seen the way we've done deals over the years, they know we're straightforward, cards in the table, we identify all the issues upfront and if we signed a deal, there's no drama, we get to the finish line, and we pay what we said we want to pay. So you put it all together, and I like our position.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could, I would like to give that over to Bill first and that Bill pioneered our integration strategy and how we execute integration and lead the teams and did it very well. Now he's our Chief Operating Officer, so he's not doing just the West Coast b
componenttext: If I could, I would like to give that over to Bill first and that Bill pioneered our integration strategy and how we execute integration and lead the teams and did it very well. Now he's our Chief Operating Officer, so he's not doing just the West Coast but everywhere. But Bill, really, built the template that we use today, so Bill why don't you to talk about it?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Mike. So what we do is we think a very patient and balanced approach to our integration. Jon and I go in and set the stage initially going into the acquisition stores laying the groundwork and foundational component of how the transition
componenttext: Okay, thank you, Mike. So what we do is we think a very patient and balanced approach to our integration. Jon and I go in and set the stage initially going into the acquisition stores laying the groundwork and foundational component of how the transition is going to take place. When I talk about patients, we don't try to sit here and put a switch for one day to the next go from being a legacy store into an AutoNation store, but over several months, we've perfected a process of being able to integrate them into our systems, our processes and our pay plans. And then one unique thing that we're able to do because they were sizing our scale is, we call a buddy system, probably can't think of a better name, but we actually current AutoNation associates from the General Manager, all the way to individual department heads to partner in the stores during the transition period so they actually have up here  a mentor on able basis to help guide them through the transaction and the transition. The last I think we're up to 10 to 12 stores that we put on that way. We had a very, very low turnover rate, a high adoption rate and then been able to hit our performance target.

componenttext: Mike, no. I think the [indiscernible] executed extraordinarily well and as we track our returns on transactions, being able to integrate smoothly and have the skill set is just one of the many advantages of AutoNation.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, let's build on the M&A. You guys have covered it pretty thoroughly here, but maybe just on the environments. One of the things we've heard from others is that, it's getting harder to make deals just when people are looking forward to $17 mil
componenttext: Yes, I guess, let's build on the M&A. You guys have covered it pretty thoroughly here, but maybe just on the environments. One of the things we've heard from others is that, it's getting harder to make deals just when people are looking forward to $17 million SAAR, using 12 months, looking historical multiples. So obviously, you've managed to put together some pretty large transactions that doesn't seem to be a barrier for you but just wanted your comments on that.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as a fair comment, we very much negotiate an additional auto criteria I called out, but the most important one is with sellers who make up their mind to sell. Now people who are checking the market to see if they can get the sun, the moon, t
componenttext: Well, I think as a fair comment, we very much negotiate an additional auto criteria I called out, but the most important one is with sellers who make up their mind to sell. Now people who are checking the market to see if they can get the sun, the moon, the sky and everything else, but it's not really for sale, it's just for sale if they can get a too good to be true price, and those discussions are out there. We identify those rather quickly, move on. We observe most of the time those businesses don't actually sell. Occasionally, someone will actually step up and pay the price and buy it, and that's fine, can't do every deal, that's for sure. Someone else is a different point of view, okay, that's going to happen, and you have to be willing to do that. If you're going to say disciplined on price. So I think the key point you mentioned is, obviously, a $17 million SAAR. Some people who are maybe sellers, not really concluded the sale, we'll check the market, and you'll hear stories about what they're asking. And occasionally, somebody will pay the price.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. I just wanted to go back to the third-party lead discussion. Again, taking some of the feedback from a couple of competitors here, what they've tended to site was they needed them just because they have the perception of objectivity, right? Pe
componenttext: Understood. I just wanted to go back to the third-party lead discussion. Again, taking some of the feedback from a couple of competitors here, what they've tended to site was they needed them just because they have the perception of objectivity, right? People want to go to something that's not affiliated with one particular dealer because they feel they will do a better job of comparing competitors and give them an output that they can use that better some way. And yet again, you've done a really good job of managing to lower your lead providers in spite of that. And I guess, I just wanted to get your thoughts, what are you guys doing differently to sort of combat that perception? Maybe its brand, maybe its technology, I'm just risen that.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So no question, we're a company that thinks when everyone else is lagging, I mean, that's an disputable. Here's the way, I think, about it, I came to the conclusion several years ago that building a brand with genuine attributes was the only way to c
componenttext: Yes. So no question, we're a company that thinks when everyone else is lagging, I mean, that's an disputable. Here's the way, I think, about it, I came to the conclusion several years ago that building a brand with genuine attributes was the only way to compete and win in this marketplace and not be disrupted and become a warehouse fulfillment center for others. That's really where I didn't want to end up. So then when you say you have a brand, the brand has to stand for something, and you see what we're doing everything from our recall policy, to Drive Pink, to our fair pricing and are very -- and capabilities in our digital side. So they are not informational, they're transactional. It took a lot of money and a lot of efforts to make that happen. So here's my point, there is a place in the marketplace -- in the market for third-party lead providers. There are dealers where it's appropriate that they do business with them. But here's the way, I think, about it, every dollar I spend on marketing today, deals a car today and sales a car tomorrow because I'm building a brand. And if I'm diverting, 30%, 40%, ultimately 50% of my marketing budget to build somebody else's brand, will play out where that ends. So that's why the third quarter is so important, we were leading up to it, it was our pivot. And clearly, it works. And in my view, every year, AutoNation is going to be stronger than the year before and all the benefits that comes from that. And so that gives us a relevancy and approachability and an; attractiveness in the marketplace that can cut through all the other choices that consumers have and give us a very interesting and compelling business. But it has to be genuine, and you have to take risk, you have to take short-term disruption in order to get that differentiation, and we are doing that.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's clear that looks like it certainly paying off at this point. Is there, I guess, you said you're down to 9% of sales with traditionally providers?
componenttext: Yes, it's clear that looks like it certainly paying off at this point. Is there, I guess, you said you're down to 9% of sales with traditionally providers?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Is there a point where that can get to 0? Is there always going to be a role for them from you guys?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So here's the next discussion with the 9%, if they provide a role for the AutoNation brand on their site, we can have a good partnership. As long as I can raise the flag at my brand on their site in a compelling way, we can have a partnership because I'm
componenttext: So here's the next discussion with the 9%, if they provide a role for the AutoNation brand on their site, we can have a good partnership. As long as I can raise the flag at my brand on their site in a compelling way, we can have a partnership because I'm building my brand. If the rules of the game are that, they, listen, you're paying me for traffic, and we're not talking about AutoNation and what you are, then that's going to be a more difficult conversation. So those negotiations will probably take the next quarter or so. And when I see hold that those, can probably give you a pretty good idea of where it's going to settle down, settle in. And if I have an appropriate positioning for my brand, then I'm really going to view them not as a third-party lead provider, I'm going to view them as a partner with AutoNation. I'm looking for a win-win partnership. And if I find that, we can have a long-term relationship.

componenttext: Going back to acquisitions, Mike, it seems like you've seen deals come to you a bit more. Do you feel a flat year-on-year SAAR can actually bring more deals to you and more than offset any organic growth slowdown in you?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Predict saying forward deals is, again, not a road I want to go down. I really want to have the flexibility that when the opportunity -- and I said in the past, when the opportunity was there, we were going to move, we're not afraid to increase leverage o
componenttext: Predict saying forward deals is, again, not a road I want to go down. I really want to have the flexibility that when the opportunity -- and I said in the past, when the opportunity was there, we were going to move, we're not afraid to increase leverage on the company to move, we'll move. If they're not attractive deals, they don't strategically fit, it's not cultural fit, the price is too high, then we're not going to do the deal. And it is very difficult to predict what's even going to happen next quarter or next year. We have a lot of interesting discussions ongoing. I hope to have additional deals to do, but you'll never know.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Just a quick follow-up for Jon. Why gain more exposure to Texas at this point given that could be some concerns around the retail environment or the consumer sentiment there?
componenttext: Got it. Just a quick follow-up for Jon. Why gain more exposure to Texas at this point given that could be some concerns around the retail environment or the consumer sentiment there?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paresh, Texas is an excellent long-term market for us, so we're very comfortable operating in Texas. We've been there for a long time. Our stores performed very well in those markets and the fit was just outstanding in terms of the markets and the st
componenttext: Yes, Paresh, Texas is an excellent long-term market for us, so we're very comfortable operating in Texas. We've been there for a long time. Our stores performed very well in those markets and the fit was just outstanding in terms of the markets and the store locations and the brands, in particular, with Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep, Ram and Chevrolet, Allen Samuels offers a strong truck portfolio that fits very well into Texas. And then from a cultural fit standpoint that Mike talked about and Bill as well on the onboarding, it was just an ideal fit for us. So there are a lot of factors that came together, and we're very optimistic about operating in Texas long-term.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the M&A thing and ask about why the deals are kind of coming to fruition now. Is there perhaps some softening on seller expectations? Or do you see incremental synergies that you can get given the progress on the brand, Mike?
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the M&A thing and ask about why the deals are kind of coming to fruition now. Is there perhaps some softening on seller expectations? Or do you see incremental synergies that you can get given the progress on the brand, Mike? Or is it the combination of the 2? Just amount of color there would be helpful.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination of the 2. And I would also observe of the $1.7 billion of deals we've announced for this year, fully $1 billion is Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep and Ram. And I think there may be a difference in point of view about the long-term outlook
componenttext: I think it's a combination of the 2. And I would also observe of the $1.7 billion of deals we've announced for this year, fully $1 billion is Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep and Ram. And I think there may be a difference in point of view about the long-term outlook, can't say for sure, but it is $1 billion out of the $1.7 billion. And it's a clear expression of my confidence and optimism about those brands in the U.S. I love the fact that it's all 4 brands under one roof and that Chrysler Corporation continues to differentiate and make genuine differences in those brands. I've seen the product portfolio for the next several years, it's very compelling. But there are those who observed that Chrysler Corporation has been a boom and bust. And if you're thinking about filling something, maybe while everything is fine, it's a good thing to do it. So I think that's a factor of $1 billion out of $1.7 billion.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, to be clear, the TrueCar traffic had nothing to do with our website. That's traffic that -- those leads go directly to our dealerships, and we basically are paying for the traffic. It has nothing to do with AutoNation brand or nothing to do with Auto
componenttext: Yes, to be clear, the TrueCar traffic had nothing to do with our website. That's traffic that -- those leads go directly to our dealerships, and we basically are paying for the traffic. It has nothing to do with AutoNation brand or nothing to do with AutoNation sites and that was my issue. And at the end of the day, as you heard me say, in order to actually close transactions for that traffic, you will really into a reverse auction process with competitor that generally lead to an unsatisfactory results for us. So it's 2 completely different things. So I assure you the fact that we've gone from years ago that the AutoNation sites generated less than 10% of the business to over 25% of the business fairly dramatic increase in traffic to AutoNation sites. That's better experience for customers and a higher close rate and a better financial results for the company. So it's a win-win-win strategy.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I sort of alluded to that earlier. I don't think there's any question about it. And I think that's on both sides. Sellers, of course, they're concerned about price, but they are very concerned about what happens to the business that they built and th
componenttext: Yes, I sort of alluded to that earlier. I don't think there's any question about it. And I think that's on both sides. Sellers, of course, they're concerned about price, but they are very concerned about what happens to the business that they built and through their associates that have been very loyal to them in building this enterprise. And they have a great -- they have a feeling that with AutoNation acquiring and putting the AutoNation brand and all the capabilities we bring to the table and the career opportunities we offer their associates. They really feel that not only are they getting a fair price, but they're really doing the right thing for their associates. And they see and feel the complexity of both from the third-party, which in many ways is like competition and how disruptive they are, the demands of the manufacturer, the amount of capital required, the amount of expertise required. And they see that we provide all of that. So we're really a take home for the business they built and associates they care about that we are giving them a bright future, and that is part of the equation, no question.

componenttext: As AutoNation brand that we're building coast-to-coast, no competitor is even trying to match it, and it's really differentiate us in a way that's never been done before. componenttext: First, I want to applaud AutoNation on the recall policy. Great to see a dealer group doing that. The question that I have this morning is when it comes to the differential of your in-house, the website and I think you mentioned it was maybe $800 or $900 difference. Can you sort of box where you're getting the advantage versus a third party? I mean, obviously there is, as you said, maintenance fees and commission fees. But I just want to get an idea of what are the other categories that are out there.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of the other things that I said, too, is not only is it on the front end margin so as Mike mentioned on new vehicle margins, they're stronger when we generate those directly, but also we get benefits from customer financial services. So when you blend
componenttext: One of the other things that I said, too, is not only is it on the front end margin so as Mike mentioned on new vehicle margins, they're stronger when we generate those directly, but also we get benefits from customer financial services. So when you blend those 2 together, on average, it's $800 or higher on a PVR basis combined direct versus using third parties, you tend to have different customers that are targeting the business.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you, got you. And then on the -- want to sort of dive a little bit into just M&A in general for you guys. What's the balancing act between, if it's a good fit, price or if it's even, might I say a turnaround story? I mean, how does that all sort of fi
componenttext: Got you, got you. And then on the -- want to sort of dive a little bit into just M&A in general for you guys. What's the balancing act between, if it's a good fit, price or if it's even, might I say a turnaround story? I mean, how does that all sort of fit into the overall equation? I mean, if it's a really, really good deal and let's say, culturally, it's not 100% good fit, I mean, how do you guys balance all of that out?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We were very reluctant to do transactions that are not a cultural fit. To buy a business, to shut it down and rebuilt it from ground up is not something that we are enthusiastic to do. So we passed on a lot of deals that we just didn't think we could inte
componenttext: We were very reluctant to do transactions that are not a cultural fit. To buy a business, to shut it down and rebuilt it from ground up is not something that we are enthusiastic to do. So we passed on a lot of deals that we just didn't think we could integrate without tremendous disruption. So, Jon, why don't  you talk about our criteria?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we look at -- we got brand market return criteria is, so we're looking for excellent retail locations. As Mike said, we're looking for a good cultural fit so that we can successfully onboard employees and transition the business profitably and succes
componenttext: Yes, we look at -- we got brand market return criteria is, so we're looking for excellent retail locations. As Mike said, we're looking for a good cultural fit so that we can successfully onboard employees and transition the business profitably and successfully. We certainly get our return criteria so it got to meet our financial return metrics so, we're looking at the demographics in the market and if it's a good brand fit for that market, so buying, again, Chrysler and Chevy in Texas with a pickup truck mix is ideal. Similarly, last year in Bellevue, Washington, we bought a Mercedes-Benz, Audi and Porsche stores so that brand, mix and cultural fit is excellent. So we're balancing all of those factors now have to come together and fit back in to what Mike said earlier that if you look at our batting average, if you want to look at it that way, it's about 100, we'll look at 10 deals and pass on 9 that don't meet our criteria, and we'll do the 1 deal. And we feel like last 3 years, if you look at the mix of acquisitions that we've done, they fit very well across all of our streaming criteria, and we're very happy with that. And we'll continue to be disciplined in that way.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last question for Mike Jackson. What are you thinking from an overall industry standpoint, sales going to in 2016? And if I may sort of push you a little bit, maybe even 2017.
componenttext: Last question for Mike Jackson. What are you thinking from an overall industry standpoint, sales going to in 2016? And if I may sort of push you a little bit, maybe even 2017.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as you, all, recall, I think it was after the second quarter of 2014, I forecasted 17 million vehicles for this year, and it's clear now, we'll break through 17 million. So I don't  know whether it's going to be 17.2 million, 17.3 million, doesn't ma
componenttext: Yes, as you, all, recall, I think it was after the second quarter of 2014, I forecasted 17 million vehicles for this year, and it's clear now, we'll break through 17 million. So I don't  know whether it's going to be 17.2 million, 17.3 million, doesn't matter, it's going to be great. And I think next year, we'll definitely break through 17 million again. Whether it exceeds this year, comes out the same or a little bit more, I can't say today. But I think even with somewhat higher interest rates, if it's 100 basis points next year and that still and if at this point but, let's say, all in 100 basis points, that's 15 a month, 15 hours a month for our customers, that can easily be dealt with. If you combine that with still pent-up demand, the products and the manufacturers are absolutely sensational. I see no signs of gasolines going back to $3.50 next year, so I'm very optimistic about 2016. I think it will be 17 million again. Thank you, everyone, for your time today. Really enjoy discussing our business. Thank you very much.

Welcome to AutoNation's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Andrew Wamser, Treasurer and Vice President of Investor Relations for AutoNation. Sir, you may begin.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call and Webcast. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill B
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to AutoNation's Third Quarter 2015 Conference Call and Webcast. 
Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman, CEO and President; Cheryl Miller, our Chief Financial Officer; Bill Berman, our Chief Operating Officer; and Jon Ferrando, our Executive Vice President responsible for M&A. 
Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Robert Quartaro and I will also be available via phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have. 
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments. Certain statements and information on this call may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from such forward-looking statements. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our press release issued earlier today and our SEC filings, including our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K and subsequent quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules will be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release and on our website located at investors.autonation.com. 
And now I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman, CEO and President, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.05, a 17% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $0.90 for the same period in the prior year. This is
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we reported an all-time record earnings per share from continuing operations of $1.05, a 17% increase as compared to EPS from continuing operations of $0.90 for the same period in the prior year. This is our 20th consecutive quarter of double-digit year-over-year growth in EPS from continuing operations. 
Third quarter 2015 revenue totaled $5.4 billion compared to $4.9 billion in the year ago period, an increase of 9%, driven by stronger performance in all of our business sectors. 
Total gross profit was $830 million compared to $753 million in the year ago period, an increase of 10%. Operating income was $236 million compared to $207 million in the year ago period, an increase of 14%. 
In the third quarter, AutoNation's retail new vehicle unit sales increased by 7% or 5% on a same-store basis. 
Today, AutoNation also announced the acquisition of Allen Samuels Auto Group, 12 stores with approximately $800 million in annual revenue, spanning across 6 Texas markets. 
Since the beginning of 2015, we have announced acquisitions with roughly $1.7 billion in annual revenue, of which $1 billion is Chrysler, Jeep, Ram, Dodge-related. 
We will continue to pursue acquisitions that leverage our scale, expand the AutoNation brand and provide strong returns for our shareholders. 
The third quarter was also pivotal for AutoNation. We continue to build the AutoNation brand, execute our digital strategy, showing our website currently represent over 25% of our unit sales and third-party leads now represent less than 9% of our unit sales. 
We did all of this and delivered an all-time record EPS from continuing operation. 
In the third quarter, we announced an unprecedented industry-leading recall policy. It's simple. We will not sell, lease, wholesale or deal or trade any new or used vehicle that has an open recall. We have made it our responsibility to identify and remove these vehicles from our inventory until their recall issues have been addressed. 
This will require us to build used inventory levels through the fourth quarter. We expect our used business to normalize in the first half of 2016 once our used inventory levels are ramped up. This is a significant brand attribute that differentiates AutoNation from -- that no competitor has matched, not even CarMax. 
I'll now turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Cheryl Miller.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. For the third quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $119 million or $1.05 per share versus net income of $107 million or $0.90 per share during the third quarter of 2014, a 17% improve
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, everyone. 
For the third quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $119 million or $1.05 per share versus net income of $107 million or $0.90 per share during the third quarter of 2014, a 17% improvement on a per share basis. There were no adjustments to net income in either periods. 
In the third quarter, revenue increased $445 million or 9% compared to the prior year and gross profit improved $77 million or 10%. 
SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 68.5% for the quarter, which represents a 90 basis point decrease compared to the year ago period. The provision for income tax in the quarter was $76.3 million or 39.1%. 
On September 21, we issued $750 million of senior unsecured notes, consisting of $300 million of notes at 3.35%, which are scheduled to mature in 2021 as well as $450 million of notes at 4.5%, which are scheduled to mature in 2025. 
The transaction represented our debut investment-grade bond financing and was extremely well received by investors. The note proceeds were primarily used to reduce borrowings under our existing revolving credit facility. This resulted in an increase in our percentage of fixed rate nonvehicle debt to 80% at the end of the quarter from 48% at June 30, 2015. 
Returning to third quarter results. Net new vehicle floorplan was a benefit of $17 million, an increase of $2 million from the third quarter of 2014, primarily due to increased new vehicle unit sales as well as higher floorplan assistance rate per unit. 
Floorplan debt decreased sequentially, approximately $118 million during the third quarter to $3.2 billion at quarter end, primarily due to reduced borrowings under our used vehicle floorplan facilities. 
Nonvehicle interest expense decreased slightly to $21.4 million compared to $21.7 million in the third quarter of 2014. 
The decrease in interest expense was driven by lower interest rates associated with the refinancing of our credit facility in December 2014 and the establishment of our commercial paper program in May of this year. 
At the end of September, we had $2.2 billion of nonvehicle debt, an increase of $77 million compared to June 30, 2015. Nonvehicle debt includes $435 million of outstanding commercial paper borrowings. 
At the end of September, we had no amounts drawn under our revolving credit facility. 
I'll also note that we have no material debt maturities until late 2017. 
During the third quarter 2015, we repurchased 2.5 million shares for $150 million at an average price of $59.83 per share. 
As of October 26, we had approximately $297 million of board authorization remaining for share repurchase and there were approximately 111 million shares outstanding. This does not include the dilutive impact of stock option. 
Our leverage ratio remained at 2.2x at the end of Q3 as compared to Q2. The leverage ratio was 2.0x on a net debt basis, including used floorplan availability and our covenant limit is 3.75x. 
Capital expenditures were $27.9 million for the quarter. Capital expenditures are on an accrual basis and exclude operating lease buyouts and related asset sales. 
Our quarter end cash balance was $64 million, which, combined with our additional borrowing capacity, resulted in total liquidity of $1.8 billion at the end of September. We continue to use our revolving credit facility as a liquidity backstop for borrowings under our commercial paper program. As I mentioned a moment ago, we had $435 million of commercial paper outstanding at year end, which, in effect, at quarter end -- which in effect, reduces available liquidity to $1.3 billion. 
We continue to leverage our strong operating results and cash flow generation in order to make strategic investments in our business in addition to opportunistic acquisitions and share repurchase. 
Now let me turn you over to our Chief Operating Officer, Bill Berman.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cheryl, and good morning, everyone. AutoNation posted record results in the third quarter. We set an all-time record in EPS from continuing operations. This was our 20th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth. Going forward, my comm
componenttext:
Thank you, Cheryl, and good morning, everyone. 
AutoNation posted record results in the third quarter. We set an all-time record in EPS from continuing operations. This was our 20th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth. 
Going forward, my comments will be on a same-store basis when compared to the period a year ago unless noted otherwise. 
Gross profit for variable operations was $467 million, up 6%. Variable gross was $3,282 on a per vehicle retail basis, an increase of $103 or 3%. New and used same-store unit volumes was up 3%. New vehicle revenue for the quarter was $3 billion, an increase of $201 million or 7%. We retailed 87,400 units, an increase of 5%. 
New vehicle gross profit was $1,877 on a per vehicle retail basis, which was relatively flat compared to the same period a year ago. 
We are pleased with our new vehicle PVR performance for the quarter. In the fourth quarter, we expect a sequential increase in PVRs in the $200 range due to the seasonal mixed shift towards Premium Luxury. 
Our pivotal way from less profitable third-party lead providers helped offset new PVR competitor pressures, new vehicle PVRs from our self-generated sales, including customer financial services are approximately $800 higher than new vehicle PVRs from third-party sales. 
Regarding our digital strategy, AutoNation websites currently generate over 25% of our unit sales. Sales from third-party leads now represent under 9% of our unit sales. 
Used vehicle retail revenue for the quarter was $1.1 billion, an increase of $24 million or 2% compared to the period a year ago. Used vehicles retail were relatively flat year-over-year at 55,900. 
Used vehicle gross profit was $1,509 on a vehicle retail basis, a decrease of $112 or 7%. 
As Mike mentioned in the third quarter, we set an auto retail industry standard and decided not to sell, lease or wholesale any new or used vehicle that has an open recall. 
As of September 30, 6% of our inventory, which represents less than 2% of our new vehicle inventory and approximately 16% of our used vehicle inventory, was not available for sale due to open recalls. We will continue to build our used vehicle inventory levels to ensure we have adequate supply to meet customer demand. 
In the third quarter, our used vehicle sales were slowed by our recall policy, and we expect to see an impact in the fourth quarter as well. Putting our customers first is the right thing to do. We believe the short-term investments are outweighed by the long-term safety benefits for our customers and supports the AutoNation brand promise.
Customer financial services gross profit was $1,549 on a per vehicle retail basis, an increase of $146 or 10%. 
Total gross profit per customer financial services of $222 million was up $26 million or 14% compared to the period a year ago. 
In the quarter, customer care revenue was an all-time record at $757 million, an increase of $44 million or 6%. 
We set another all-time record in customer care gross profit of $330 million, an increase of $28 million or 9%. 
Customer pay gross was $129 million, up 7%, our 21st consecutive quarterly increase in customer pay gross profit. 
Warranty gross was $67 million, up 15%. Collision gross was $30 million, up 13%. 
In the third quarter, we announced the Drive Pink campaign from coast-to-coast. Our Drive Pink campaign ties into the first-ever AutoNation Cure Bowl, which we held at the Orlando Citrus Bowl on December 19 to benefit the breast cancer research foundation. AutoNation has pledged to donate $1 million to support BCRF. I would like to thank our 25,000 associates and our customers for partnering with AutoNation to raise $1 million for breast cancer research. 
Finally, I would like to welcome the Valley Motors Auto Group associates to the AutoNation family. 
I'll now turn the call over to Jon Ferrando, Executive Vice President responsible for M&A.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. We are very excited today to announce the acquisition of the Allen Samuels Auto Group in Texas. In connection with the transaction, we will acquire 12 stores to generate approximately [indiscernible]  In annu
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. 
We are very excited today to announce the acquisition of the Allen Samuels Auto Group in Texas. In connection with the transaction, we will acquire 12 stores to generate approximately [indiscernible]  In annual revenue and retail 19,500 new and used vehicles annually. 
Stores are located in the Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston, Corpus Christi, Tyler, Ennis and Waco markets. The franchise represented include Chrysler, Dodge, Jeep, Ram, Chevrolet, Hyundai, Mercedes-Benz and Sprinter. 
The acquisition is consistent with our strategy of enhancing brand representation in sales in our markets and the strong truck product offering of Allen Samuels makes it a great fit in Texas. 
Closing of the transaction is subject to customary closing conditions, including manufacturer approval. We expect the transaction to close in Q1 2016. On completing the Allen Samuels acquisition, AutoNation will have 53 stores in the State of Texas. 
We look forward to welcoming the more than 1,000 Allen Samuels associates and tens of thousands of new customers to the AutoNation family. 
Also, in September, we completed the previously announced acquisition of Valley Motors in the Baltimore market,and we're on track to complete in Q4 the acquisition of 13 stores in Georgia, Alabama and Tennessee from Carl Gregory. 
In 2015, AutoNation has announced the acquisition of 33 stores, generating approximately $1.7 billion in annual revenue and since Q4 2012, AutoNation has announced acquisitions and new franchises awarded by the manufacturers that will generate $3.3 billion in annual revenue once fully operational. 
As of today, our store portfolio numbers 307 franchises and 240 stores in 15 states, representing 35 manufacturer brands. These numbers will grow to 372 franchises and 265 stores upon completion of the Carl Gregory and Allen Samuels acquisition. 
Looking forward, we will continue to actively pursue acquisitions and new store opportunities with a focus on enhancing brand representation within our existing markets and markets that can be supported by our existing management infrastructure. We will continue to be selective and prudent with our capital with a focus on investing to produce strong returns and long-term shareholder value. 
I will now turn it back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. I'd like to thank all our associates for their efforts with our Drive Pink campaign, which has been a tremendous success, and I look forward to seeing all of you at the AutoNation Cure Bowl in December. I'd now be delighted to take your
componenttext:
Thank you, John. I'd like to thank all our associates for their efforts with our Drive Pink campaign, which has been a tremendous success, and I look forward to seeing all of you at the AutoNation Cure Bowl in December. 
I'd now be delighted to take your questions.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jamie Albertine from Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jamie Albertine from Stifel.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to ask on the used retail side. Thank you for the additional color with respect to the recall campaign. If you could maybe tell us a little bit more or shed some more light on what the cadence of used vehicle sales would have looked like x th
componenttext: I was hoping to ask on the used retail side. Thank you for the additional color with respect to the recall campaign. If you could maybe tell us a little bit more or shed some more light on what the cadence of used vehicle sales would have looked like x that campaign. Is there any granularity you can provide?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Jackson. It's very difficult to say what the missed opportunity was, so I'm very -- I'm not enthusiastic about putting an actual number on there other than to say there was an opportunity impact. Obviously, our used vehicle sales were stable. We
componenttext: It's Mike Jackson. It's very difficult to say what the missed opportunity was, so I'm very -- I'm not enthusiastic about putting an actual number on there other than to say there was an opportunity impact. Obviously, our used vehicle sales were stable. We had some impact on the gross as it took longer to prepare vehicles, to have them frontline ready. And there is some disruption. But we think we're going to work through all those issues over the next quarter and starting sometime in the first half of next year, go back to growing the used vehicle business and improving the grosses. There are -- there will be some permanent hard cost in that we're going to increase inventory to allow for, on the used side, 10% to 15% of it to be tied up at all times with open recall. But I think that cost is very manageable, you can do the math on that. Building the technology systems to manage it all both to identify the open recalls every day and to manage the process of getting them all repaired, that's all underway. That's, again, a manageable cost, and it's a onetime cost. But clearly, there's some opportunity that we missed in the quarter because of this step that we've taken. In my view, it's hard to put a number on that, but if you weigh the cost benefit both for what it needs for the industry that we're taking a leadership position in something that's clearly a black eye for the industry at the moment, namely the recall situation that AutoNation is going to part of the solution, not part of the problem, that we put our customers first, the safety of our customers first is a clear brand statement. And we see that the strength of our brand is, every year, more evident. And all you have to do is look at on the new vehicle side where we pivoted away from dependence on traffic bought from third parties to relying on our brand and our own sites and investing in those, the strength that, that gave us to a unique brand attribute like the recall policy to positioning in the marketplace that the company really cares about big issues such as the fight against cancer and right now the Drive Pink is focused on breast cancer awareness and raising funds to find a cure. I think all of this is very compelling. And so yes, in used cars, we have some lost opportunity for a few quarters. But in the grand scheme of things, I think we're on a convincing and compelling growth. Because the hardest thing to do in business is to open a sustainable competitive advantage. And I think the evidence is becoming clearer and clearer that AutoNation is doing something special.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate the color and we would agree with the long-term outlook as well. If I may, along those same lines, just a quick follow-up. You've talked about these in the last couple of years some spending around your digital initiatives, the coast-to-coast
componenttext: I appreciate the color and we would agree with the long-term outlook as well. If I may, along those same lines, just a quick follow-up. You've talked about these in the last couple of years some spending around your digital initiatives, the coast-to-coast branding. It seems to us, just based on the data that you're providing, as it relates to lead generation and so forth, that those investments are starting to leverage themselves? Just some additional color there would be great in terms of the returns you're seeing on those investments. And then if, at all, there are sort of further sort of supplementary investments that you're going to look to make in the near term that we should consider from our modeling.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the third quarter is the proof in the pudding. That exactly what you described is happening on the digital side and the fact that if I just look at the new car business, which was primarily where Costco and TrueCar was, Cheryl, I think was around 7%
componenttext: Yes, the third quarter is the proof in the pudding. That exactly what you described is happening on the digital side and the fact that if I just look at the new car business, which was primarily where Costco and TrueCar was, Cheryl, I think was around 7% of our business, something like 7% of our new car business we walked away from and yet we had an outstanding performance. So if you want clear evidence that the power of the brand is taking hold and that our -- the enhancement of our digital sites making it a better customer experience is worthwhile. And if you want -- to me, the biggest proof is look at our front-end gross new vehicles, up $33. So we walk -- the business we walked away from with TrueCar and Costco haven't have -- their front end gross on average was $900 less than the business coming through AutoNation channels. So we left our most unprofitable business behind us, our most expensive business to acquire. It weakened our brand, it did not strengthen our brand. And that's why I think the third quarter is uncontestable proof that the strategy we've been talking about, investing in, has been validated, and that we're getting tremendous benefit from it. We have probably, on the pure technology side, passed the peak investment periods, but substantial investment is yet to come.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Murphy from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Murphy from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a first question on the recall policy. I mean sort of the flip side of this is that you're going to have potentially a greater capture of warranty here. And I'm just curious, have you thought about that sort of the offset and how big an offset would
componenttext: Just a first question on the recall policy. I mean sort of the flip side of this is that you're going to have potentially a greater capture of warranty here. And I'm just curious, have you thought about that sort of the offset and how big an offset would that be to the cost of carrying that inventory?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I think the fact that we'll do all that work is true, but I don't -- I really don't think it begins to offset the length of time, additional length of time it takes to get used vehicles frontline ready. So it's more about the brand and more about be
componenttext: John, I think the fact that we'll do all that work is true, but I don't -- I really don't think it begins to offset the length of time, additional length of time it takes to get used vehicles frontline ready. So it's more about the brand and more about being part of the solution for an industry black eyed and the fact that we'll actually do more recall work. There is an issue out there floating that if -- the new vehicle dealers in the United States are authorized and have the technical skill to make these repairs and completion rates are not acceptable, and you hear regulators talking about the fact, well, if the new vehicle dealers and the manufacturers can't figure out how to get these repairs done faster and in a higher level, we're going to open it up to everyone else. And I think that would be not a good development on any side. And I, for one, believe when you have an issue in the industry, be part of the solution. It's a genuine issue for our customers. The irony is, I think, most customers think the repairs are already done. So that's what's behind it. Yes, we will do additional recall work, but it really doesn't offset the disruption and the speed to market of our used vehicles.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And a second question. I mean obviously, you're on a large acquisition tier here, but you're also being reasonably aggressive with buying back shares. And it seems like as, Cheryl, as you kind of outlined, you do have a fair amount o
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And a second question. I mean obviously, you're on a large acquisition tier here, but you're also being reasonably aggressive with buying back shares. And it seems like as, Cheryl, as you kind of outlined, you do have a fair amount of capacity given your current companies to do a lot more. Just curious how you think about this capital allocation going forward with that much room and really that much opportunity. I mean it just -- it seems like you're pressing the pedal a lot harder than you have in the past and you've done a very good job in the past as well. But how much more opportunity you think there is in the future? Are we going to be looking at another $1.7 billion in acquired revenue over the next 12 months and another big share buyback in place? I mean how far can you push this?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take it first, and then I'll turn it over to Cheryl. The one thing that's not changed in all of this is our threshold on returns, that remains the same. We look for acquisitions that are a strategic fit for us, fit on our model where we want to be, 1
componenttext: I'll take it first, and then I'll turn it over to Cheryl. The one thing that's not changed in all of this is our threshold on returns, that remains the same. We look for acquisitions that are a strategic fit for us, fit on our model where we want to be, 1/3, domestic; 1/3, Asian; 1/3, German. And our cultural fit with our company and certainly, these acquisitions are a cultural fit. Sometimes, there is a difference in point of view about the future of a certain company. I, for one, am very optimistic and confident about the team at Chrysler. So I have no hesitation buying big on Chrysler. I'm all in. And so you'll see some time a streak like that come long. Now as I said before, when we look at 100 deals, we maybe do 10. So there's a lot of discussions, a lot of conversations going on and it has to meet all the threshold to meet that. We have a level of conversation that we could do a lot of deals next year. Whether they'll meet all that criteria or not, I don't know. And what I very much like is keeping the flexibility that I can do 0 next year or I can do $2 billion next year. I'm not going to get -- I'm not going to nail myself to a cross on that. It really is dependent. The same thing on share repurchase, it's opportunistic. If the opportunity is there on both share repurchase and acquisitions, am I comfortable with a higher level of leverage? Absolutely. Cheryl, why don't you talk about that?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So John, one of the things I would point out, acquisitions come with EBITDA. So when we think about, just as we've said over the years, we look at balanced approach. So if the stock or the market is out of favor, we'll buy opportunistically. If the a
componenttext: Yes. So John, one of the things I would point out, acquisitions come with EBITDA. So when we think about, just as we've said over the years, we look at balanced approach. So if the stock or the market is out of favor, we'll buy opportunistically. If the acquisition market is strong, we'll buy. We won't shave acquisition. So I think if you rollback 2 years ago, we were patient, we were looking primarily for good dealerships that fit our existing footprint or platforms in other areas that might be a good fit for us, right? So we've stayed disciplined. We haven't shaved things internationally. We continue to [indiscernible] the nice thing now as we're starting to see some of these deals hit, and we've been positioned for this. So with the strength in our base cash operating business, combined with the EBITDA we get with the acquisitions knowing that will, in an acquisition, increase the EBITDA, it gives us a lot of flexibility to do both. SO I think we're in a great situation from a liquidity standpoint. And from a leverage standpoint, this balanced approach gives you an opportunity where some of the capital allocation actually comes with accretive EBITDA as well.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And John, one more factor that you have to put in there today versus the past is the strength of the brand, AutoNation. So think about it. So we buy the Allen Samuels group in Texas. Great name, fine, everything. We're going to rebrand those stores AutoNa
componenttext: And John, one more factor that you have to put in there today versus the past is the strength of the brand, AutoNation. So think about it. So we buy the Allen Samuels group in Texas. Great name, fine, everything. We're going to rebrand those stores AutoNation. And as good as the legacy names are, they're not as good as the brand name AutoNation and all the attributes that come with it. Also, we take all the marketing communication moneys that's being spent by the Allen Samuels group. Not to save, but to put behind the AutoNation name. So then our whole presence in the State of Texas goes up by another factor. And it begins to feed on itself. And therefore, our confidence that we can execute on our plan to hit our return and the amount of risk involved, the risk goes down and the confidence goes up all because of the brand AutoNation. That's what a brand is doing for us at this point. Also, sellers really like to talk to AutoNation. They've seen the way we've done deals over the years, they know we're straightforward, cards on the table, we identify all the issues upfront and if we sign a deal, there's no drama. We get to the finish line, and we pay what we said we want to pay. So you put it all together, and I like our position.

componenttextpreview: Yes, great opportunity. And low-cost capital makes for a really good situation for you. It's really fantastic.
componenttext: Yes, great opportunity. And low-cost capital makes for a really good situation for you. It's really fantastic.
