componenttextpreview: Well, we're doing 2 different tests. We have AutoNation Express, which is primarily driven on the sale side of the business. We've expanded the test to parts of Southern California as well as South Florida, and the initial results have been very strong. M
componenttext: Well, we're doing 2 different tests. We have AutoNation Express, which is primarily driven on the sale side of the business. We've expanded the test to parts of Southern California as well as South Florida, and the initial results have been very strong. Mike talked earlier about building our brand, having transactional websites, and being able to drive traffic to it. So far, all the results have been positive.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as it relates to some of the digital marketing national branding. Is that a key factor as you're looking at M&A, is that one of the things? Because it seems a lot of us are focused on there's a spike-up in M&A activity. And I think there ar
componenttext: Okay. And just as it relates to some of the digital marketing national branding. Is that a key factor as you're looking at M&A, is that one of the things? Because it seems a lot of us are focused on there's a spike-up in M&A activity. And I think there are probably a lot of reasons for it, but is one of them the strength of the national branding and the digital marketing that you offer? And does that make the transactions easier?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I sort of alluded to that earlier. I don't think there's any question about it, and I think that's on both sides. Sellers, of course, they're concerned about price, but they're very concerned about what happens to the business that they built and for
componenttext: Yes, I sort of alluded to that earlier. I don't think there's any question about it, and I think that's on both sides. Sellers, of course, they're concerned about price, but they're very concerned about what happens to the business that they built and for their associates that have been very loyal to them in building this enterprise. And there is a -- they have a great -- I have a feeling that with AutoNation acquiring and putting the AutoNation brand on it and all the capabilities we bring to the table and the career opportunities we offer their associates, they really feel that not only are they getting a fair price, but they're really doing the right thing for their associates. And they see and feel the complexity both from the third party, which, in many ways, is like competition and how disruptive they are, the demands of the manufacturers, the amount of capital required, the amount of expertise required. And they see that we provide all that. So we're really a safe home for the business they built and the associates they care about, that we are giving them a bright future, and that is part of the equation, no question.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And it seems like you're getting choice properties as well. And just -- when you look at where they're located and the size of the transaction, it looks like they're probably sought-after.
componenttext: And it seems like you're getting choice properties as well. And just -- when you look at where they're located and the size of the transaction, it looks like they're probably sought-after.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are not doing transactions for transaction's sake. We've been very patient for a very long time, but I've always said, when the opportunity is there, we will move, and we're in one of those periods. And if you're asking me what is different, I think yo
componenttext: We are not doing transactions for transaction's sake. We've been very patient for a very long time, but I've always said, when the opportunity is there, we will move, and we're in one of those periods. And if you're asking me what is different, I think your question is on the point. If you really look at this AutoNation brand that we're building coast-to-coast, no competitor is even trying to match it, and it really differentiates us in a way that's never been done before. And a lot of benefit comes from that. Dealing with the third party, setting the table for acquisitions, winning in the marketplace, building relationships with customers that's not -- that can be long term.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Lim from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Lim from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to applaud AutoNation on the recall policy. Great to see a dealer group doing that. The question that I have this morning is, when it comes to the differential of your in-house, the website -- and I think you mentioned it was maybe an $800
componenttext: First, I wanted to applaud AutoNation on the recall policy. Great to see a dealer group doing that. The question that I have this morning is, when it comes to the differential of your in-house, the website -- and I think you mentioned it was maybe an $800 or $900 difference. Can you sort of box where you're getting the advantage versus a third party? I mean obviously there is, as you said, maintenance fees and commission fees. But I just want to get an idea of what are the other categories that are out there.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Cheryl, I'm not sure I get the question.
componenttext: Cheryl, I'm not sure I get the question.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, one of the other things I'd say, too, is not only is it on the front-end margin. So as Mike mentioned on new vehicle margins, they're stronger when we generate those directly, but also we get benefits from customer financial services. So when you ble
componenttext: Yes, one of the other things I'd say, too, is not only is it on the front-end margin. So as Mike mentioned on new vehicle margins, they're stronger when we generate those directly, but also we get benefits from customer financial services. So when you blend those 2 together, on average, it's $800 or higher on a PVR basis combined direct versus using third parties, who tend to have different customers that are targeting the business.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you, got you. And then on the -- and wanted to sort of dive a little bit into just M&A in general for you guys. What's the balancing act between if it's a good fit, price or if it's even, might I say a turnaround story? I mean, how does that all sort
componenttext: Got you, got you. And then on the -- and wanted to sort of dive a little bit into just M&A in general for you guys. What's the balancing act between if it's a good fit, price or if it's even, might I say a turnaround story? I mean, how does that all sort of fit into the overall equation? I mean, if it's a really, really good deal and yet, let's say, culturally, it's not a 100% good fit. I mean how do you guys balance all of that out?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are very reluctant to do transactions that are not a cultural fit. To buy a business, to shut it down and rebuilt it from ground up is not something that we're enthusiastic to do. So we've passed on a lot of deals that we just didn't think we could int
componenttext: We are very reluctant to do transactions that are not a cultural fit. To buy a business, to shut it down and rebuilt it from ground up is not something that we're enthusiastic to do. So we've passed on a lot of deals that we just didn't think we could integrate without tremendous disruption. So Jon, why don't you talk about our criteria?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we look at -- we've got brand market and return criteria, so we're looking for excellent retail locations. As Mike said, we're looking for a good cultural fit so that we can successfully onboard employees and transition the business profitably and su
componenttext: Yes, we look at -- we've got brand market and return criteria, so we're looking for excellent retail locations. As Mike said, we're looking for a good cultural fit so that we can successfully onboard employees and transition the business profitably and successfully. We've certainly got our return criteria, so it's got to meet our financial return metrics. We're looking at the demographics in the market and if it's a good brand fit for that market. So buying, again, a Chrysler and Chevy in Texas with the pickup truck mix is ideal. Similarly, last year, in Bellevue, Washington, we bought a Mercedes-Benz, Audi and Porsche store, so that brand mix and cultural fit was excellent. So we're balancing -- all of those factors now have to come together and that feeds back into what Mike said earlier as well, that if you look at our batting average, if you want to look at it that way, it's about 100. We'll look at 10 deals and pass on 9 that don't meet our criteria, and we'll do the 1 deal. And we feel like the last 3 years, if you look at the mix of acquisitions that we've done, they've fit very well across all of our screening criteria, and we're very happy with that. And we'll continue to be disciplined in that way.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Last question for Mike Jackson. What are you thinking, from an overall industry standpoint, sales going to in 2016? And if I may sort of push you a little bit, maybe even 2017?
componenttext: Last question for Mike Jackson. What are you thinking, from an overall industry standpoint, sales going to in 2016? And if I may sort of push you a little bit, maybe even 2017?

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you all recall, I think it was after the second quarter of 2014, I forecasted 17 million vehicles for this year, and it's clear now we'll break through 17 million. So I don't know whether it's going to be 17.2 million, 17.3 million, doesn't matter
componenttext:
Yes. As you all recall, I think it was after the second quarter of 2014, I forecasted 17 million vehicles for this year, and it's clear now we'll break through 17 million. So I don't know whether it's going to be 17.2 million, 17.3 million, doesn't matter, it's going to be great. And I think next year, we'll definitely break through 17 million again. Whether it exceeds this year, comes out the same or is a little bit more, I can't say today. But I think even with somewhat higher interest rates, if it's 100 basis points next year, and that's still an if at this point, but let's say, all in, it's 100 basis points, that's 15 a month -- 15 hours a month for our customers. That can easily be dealt with. You combine that with still pent-up demand, the products and the manufacturers are absolutely sensational. I see no sign that gasoline is going back to $3.50 next year, so I'm very optimistic about 2016. I think it will be over 17 million again.
Thank you, everyone, for your time today. We really enjoy discussing our business. Thank you very much.

headline: AutoNation, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This concludes today's conference. Thank you all for joining.
componenttext: This concludes today's conference. Thank you all for joining.
